Title: MySQL acl_init() Buffer Overflow Permits Remote Authenticated Administrators to Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): 4.0.14 and prior 4.0 versions; 3.0.57 and prior versions
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in MySQL in the processing of user passwords.  An authenticated administrator can execute arbitrary code on the system.
It is reported that a function that checks MySQL user passwords does not properly validate the length of a user-supplied password field.  An authenticated user with administrative privileges can set a "Password" field to a specially crafted value that is longer than 16 characters to trigger an overlow and execute arbitrary code.  The code will run with the privileges of the MySQL server process.

The report indicates that an administrator can invoke a function (such as 'FLUSH PRIVILEGES') to trigger an overflow in acl_init().  The exploit password length must be set to a multiple of 8.

A demonstration exploit example is provided in the Source Message.

According to the report, this has been confirmed on on OpenBSD 3.3-RELEASE, FreeBSD 4.8-STABLE, and Gentoo Linux 1.4.
Impact': A remote authenticated administrator can execute arbitrary code on the system with the privileges of the MySQL process.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (4.0.15), available at:

http://www.mysql.com/downloads/mysql-4.0.html

Title: (Microsoft Access is Vulnerable) Microsoft Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) in Multiple Microsoft Products Permits Remote Code Execution
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Microsoft Visual Basic for Applications (VBA), affecting a large number of Microsoft applications.  A remote user can cause an affected application to execute arbitrary code.
eEye Digital Security reported that VBA does not properly check certain document properties passed to VBA by the host application. A remote user can create a document that, when opened by the target user, calls VBA with specially crafted parameters to trigger a buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code.  The code will run with the privileges of the target user.

According to the report, a heap overflow resides in VBE.DLL and VBE6.DLL.  The overflow can be triggered when a malicious Microsoft Office file (e.g., ".doc", ".xls") is opened.  This can be exploited via Internet Explorer (IE), as IE relies on helper applications that use VBA, the report stated.

Some demonstration exploit steps are described in the Source Message.

The following products use the vulnerable VBA application and, as a result, are vulnerable:

        * Microsoft Access 97
        * Microsoft Access 2000
        * Microsoft Access 2002
        * Microsoft Excel 97
        * Microsoft Excel 2000
        * Microsoft Excel 2002
        * Microsoft PowerPoint 97
        * Microsoft PowerPoint 2000
        * Microsoft PowerPoint 2002
        * Microsoft Project 2000
        * Microsoft Project 2002
        * Microsoft Publisher 2002
        * Microsoft Visio 2000
        * Microsoft Visio 2002
        * Microsoft Word 97
        * Microsoft Word 98(J)
        * Microsoft Word 2000
        * Microsoft Word 2002
        * Microsoft Works Suite 2001
        * Microsoft Works Suite 2002
        * Microsoft Works Suite 2003
        * Microsoft Business Solutions Great Plains 7.5
        * Microsoft Business Solutions Dynamics 6.0
        * Microsoft Business Solutions Dynamics 7.0
        * Microsoft Business Solutions eEnterprise 6.0
        * Microsoft Business Solutions eEnterprise 7.0
        * Microsoft Business Solutions Solomon 4.5
        * Microsoft Business Solutions Solomon 5.0
        * Microsoft Business Solutions Solomon 5.5
Impact': A remote user can create a malicious document that, when opened on the target system, will execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the target user.
Solution:
The vendor has released the following patches.  There are several versions available.  Make sure that you apply the proper patch.

For Microsoft Office 2000:

http://microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=E2CCE199-9C4A-4EEC-A3EC-9F738017F275&displaylang=en


For Microsoft Office XP (including Publisher 2002):

http://microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=6F1FC4B0-29E9-44E0-A33D-AD6B4B6A8FF4&displaylang=en


For Microsoft Project 2000:

http://microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=E53A52E7-431D-4580-9733-B92A2B7BFD0D&displaylang=en


For Microsoft Project 2002:

http://microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=525BDE0A-0028-488A-8209-6E07D4603CCB&displaylang=en


For Microsoft Visio 2002:

http://microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=55944490-13C2-4043-BA2A-17AF02E9C73E&displaylang=en

For Microsoft VBA Patch:

http://microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=DA1A7ABA-CD3D-458B-9729-AB9094C9BD3F&displaylang=en


Microsoft recommends that users visit Office Update to install the patch:

http://www.office.microsoft.com/ProductUpdates/default.aspx


According to the report, the Microsoft Office 2000 patch can be install on Microsoft Office 2000 SP3.  The Microsoft Office XP patch can reportedly be installed on Microsoft Office XP SP2, Microsoft Works 2002, and Microsoft Works 2003.  The Microsoft Visio 2002 patch can be installed on Microsoft Visio 2002.

The Microsoft VBA patch can reportedly be installed on:

Microsoft VBA 5.0
Microsoft VBA 6.0
Microsoft VBA 6.2
Microsoft VBA 6.3
Microsoft Access 97
Microsoft Excel 97
Microsoft PowerPoint 97
Microsoft Word 97
Microsoft Word 98(J)
Microsoft Visio 2000
Microsoft Works Suite 2001
Microsoft Business Solutions Great Plains 7.5
Microsoft Business Solutions Dynamics 6.0
Microsoft Business Solutions Dynamics 7.0
Microsoft Business Solutions eEnterprise 6.0
Microsoft Business Solutions eEnterprise 7.0
Microsoft Business Solutions Solomon 4.5
Microsoft Business Solutions Solomon 5.0
Microsoft Business Solutions Solomon 5.5 

A reboot is required after installation if 'vbe.dll' or 'vbe6.dll' is in use when the patch is installed.

Microsoft has issued Knowledge Base article 822715 regarding this flaw:

http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;en-us;822715

Title: Microsoft Access Snapshot Viewer ActiveX Control Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Microsoft Access Snapshot Viewer ActiveX control.  A remote user can cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target user's computer.
It is reported that a remote user can create HTML that, when loaded by the target user, will invoke the ActiveX control and trigger a buffer overflow, executing arbitrary code with the privileges of the target user.  This can be achieved by using a specific function in a specific manner.

The viewer is reportedly available with all versions of Access, but is not installed by default.  The viewer is also available as a standalone application.

Microsoft credits Oliver Lavery with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on a target user's system with the privileges of the target user.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following patches:

For Access 2002:

http://microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=B50D4863-1BBE-4009-9DF8-52D3A916D54F&displaylang=en

http://microsoft.com/office/ork/xp/journ/snpv1001a.htm (administrative update only)

For Access 2000:

http://microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=F6CB9C8E-16E3-422D-86DD-7ED5671FB8D4&displaylang=en.

http://microsoft.com/office/ork/2000/journ/snpv0901.htm (administrative update only)

For Access 97:

Install the updated stand-alone Snapshot Viewer control, available at:

http://www.microsoft.com/AccessDev/Articles/snapshot.htm 


The Microsoft Access 2002 patch can reportedly be installed on Microsoft Access 2002 with Office XP SP2 or, for the administrative update, on Office XP SP, as well.  The Access 2000 patch can be installed on Microsoft Access 2000 with Office 2000 SP3.  The updated stand-alone Snapshot Viewer control can be installed on all supported systems, according to the report.

A reboot is not required after applying this patch, the vendor stated.

Microsoft plans to issue Knowledge Base article 827104 regarding this issue, to be available shortly on the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://www.microsoft.com/technet/security/bulletin/%94http://search.support.microsoft.com/kb/c.asp?SD=SO&LN=EN-US%94

Title: Microsoft MDAC Database Component Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Microsoft Data Access Components (MDAC).  A remote user on the same subnet as the MDAC client can execute arbitrary code on the target client.
It is reported that a remote user can reply to a broadcast request generated by a target MDAC client with a specially crafted response to trigger a buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code on the target system.  The code will run with the privileges of the target MDAC client application that generated the request.

The report indicates that a specific component of MDAC does not validate that the specified number of bytes in the packet is a valid.

MDAC is reportedly included as part of a default installation of Windows XP, 2000, and Me.  It is also included by default in Windows Server 2003, but the version provided with Windows Server 2003 is reportedly not vulnerable.  MDAC is also available as a stand-alone component and is installed as part of other products, including Microsoft Internet Explorer and Microsoft SQL Server 2000 and others, including non-Microsoft products.

Microsoft credits Aaron C. Newman of Application Security, Inc. with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A remote user on the same subnet as the target client can cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target client.  The code will run with the privileges of the process that runs MDAC on the target client.
Solution:
Microsoft has released the following patch:

http://microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=9107ABC6-8995-4A99-B6A0-478B3A847E9C&displaylang=en

According to the advisory, the patch can be installed on MDAC 2.5 Service Pack 2, MDAC 2.5 Service Pack 3,  MAC 2.6 Service Pack 2, MDAC 2.7, and MDAC 2.7 Service Pack 1.

This fix will be included in the future MDAC 2.5 Service Pack 5 and MDAC 2.7 Service Pack 2 releases.

A reboot is required after applying this patch.

This patch supersedes the patch reported in MS02-040.

Microsoft plans to issue Knowledge Base article 823718 regarding this issue, to be available shortly at:

http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;en-us;823718

Title: Oracle Database XML Database Function Buffer Overflows Let Remote Users Access Database Sessions
Description:
Several buffer overflow vulnerabilities were reported in the Oracle Database in the XML database functions.  A remote user may be able to gain access to a user database session.
It is reported that a remote user can trigger some buffer overflows in the XML Database (XDB) functionality of the Oracle9i Database Release 2 server.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions on the server or "capture" an active user session.  If the FTP or HTTP servers are enabled, a remote user can exploit this.  Or, a remote authenticated user can exploit this.

Oracle reports that Oracle9i Database Release 1 and earlier versions are not affected.

Oracle Corporation credits David Litchfield, of Next Generation Security Software Ltd., with reporting these flaws.
Impact':
A remote user can cause denial of service conditions on the target database server.

A remote user can gain access to a user database session.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.  See the vendor's advisory for a full Patch Availability Matrix:

http://otn.oracle.com/deploy/security/pdf/2003Alert58.pdf

To apply the security patch, you must first apply the Oracle9i Database Release 2, version 9.2.0.3 patchset.

The security fix is reportedly included in the Oracle9i Database Release 2, 9.2.0.4 patchset.

The vendor does not plan to release patches for 9.0.1.x, 8.1.7.x, 8.1.6.x, 8.1.5.x, 8.0.5.x, 7.3.x, or other patchsets, as they are not affected.

The patch is available at:

http://metalink.oracle.com

Title: IBM DB2 'db2job' File Access Flaw Lets Local Users Write/Overwrite Files With Root Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the IBM DB2 database in the 'db2job' application.  A local user with certain privileges can gain root privileges.
Juan Manuel Pascual Escriba reported that a local user with privileges to execute the 'db2job' binary can write arbitrary root-owned files with mode 770 permissions (read/write/execute for root).

It is reported that './db2as/sqllib/adm/db2job' does not drop privileges before writing log files and also creates the following root-owned files:

-rw-r-----    1 root     db2asgrp /home/db2as/sqllib/db2jobht.prf
-rw-r-----    1 root     db2asgrp /home/db2as/sqllib/db2jobht.bak
-rw-r-----    1 root     db2asgrp /home/db2as/sqllib/db2jobsm.bak
-rwxrwx---    1 root     db2asgrp /home/db2as/sqllib/0_1.out

A local user can create a symbolic link from a critical file on the system to the '0_1.out' file.  Then, when 'db2job' is executed, the symlinked file will be written to with root privileges.

The vendor was reportedly notified on July 27, 2003.
Impact': A local user with privileges to execute 'db2job' can write or overwrite files with root privileges.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: IBM DB2 Database Libraries Let Local Users With 'bin' Privileges Gain 'root' Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the IBM DB2 database.  A local user with 'bin' privileges can gain root privileges on the system.
It is reported that a local user with 'bin' user privileges can create a 'so' library in the database's lib directory ('/usr/IBMdb2/V7.1/lib' on version 7.1 and '/opt/IBM/db2/V8.1/lib' on version 8.1).  The lib directory is owned by the 'bin' user and group.  The local user can create a library and then execute a database binary that has set user id (setuid) root privileges to cause the user-created code to be executed with root privileges.

A demonstration exploit is provided in the Source Message.

The vendor was reportedly notified on July 27, 2003.
Impact': A local user with 'bin' user privileges can cause the database to execute arbitrary code with root privileges.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report indicates that, as a workaround, you can change the ownership of the DB2 lib directory and libraries to 'root'.

Title: MySQL World-Writable Configuration File May Let Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Description:
An access control vulnerability was reported in MySQL.  A local user may be able to gain root privileges on the system.
It is reported that a local user can use a "SELECT * INTO OUTFILE" statement to overwrite a world-writable 'datadir/my.cnf' file with the following contents:

[mysqld]
user=root

The report indicats that the MySQL server will invoke the 'my.cnf' file in the data directory, if it exists, rather than the '/etc/my.cnf' file.  So, when the mysqld daemon is subsequently started, it will be started with root privileges instead of the privileges of the default mysql user.  The local user may be able to invoke MySQL to gain root privileges.
Impact': A local user can cause the MySQL daemon to start with root privileges instead of the normal MySQL user privileges.  This may allow the local user to gain root privileges or mysql user privileges on the system.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (3.23.56), available at:

http://www.mysql.com/downloads/index.html

Title: (Exploit Code is Available) Re: Microsoft Data/Desktop Engine Named Pipe and LPC Flaws Let Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in the Microsoft Data/Desktop Engine (MSDE).  A local user can execute arbitrary code.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.  Microsoft SQL Server is also affected.
Microsoft reported three vulnerabilities in the database products as a result of research by @stake.

In one vulnerability, a local user can connect to a port used for SQL Local Procedure Call and send a specially crafted message to overwrite the stack and execute arbitrary code (CVE-2003-0232). The code will run with the privileges of the SQL Server. The vendor was reportedly notified on February 5, 2003.

In another vulnerability, a local user may be able to hijack a named pipe to gain elevated privileges (CVE-2003-0230). The vulnerability is reportedly caused by a flaw in the method used to check for named pipes. A local user may be able to gain the privileges of the user whose session created the named pipe.

It is also reported that a remote user can send a specially crafted, large packet to a specific named pipe to cause the SQL Server to stop responding (CVE-2003-0231). The vendor was reportedly notified on January 28, 2003.

Some demonstration exploit code from Xfocus is available in the Source Message and at:

http://www.xfocus.org/exploits/200307/expMS0331.cpp
Impact':
A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with MSDE (SQL Server) permissions.

A local user may be able to gain access to a named pipe that belongs to another user to obtain the privileges of the target user.

A remote user can cause the MSDE to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following cumulative patches:

* Microsoft SQL Server 7.0

http://microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=FE5B0892-A5C9-44C2-9B42-0D291E9C1636&displaylang=en

* Microsoft SQL 2000 32-bit Edition

http://microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=9814AE9D-BD44-40C5-ADD3-B8C99618E68D&displaylang=en

* Microsoft SQL 2000 64-bit Edition 

http://microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyId=72336508-057A-4E86-8F2E-CB1BD3A6A44B&displaylang=en

The SQL Server 7.0 patch can be installed on SQL Server 7.0 SP4 or on MSDE 1.0 SP4.  The SQL Server 2000 patch can be installed on SP3 or Spa or on MSDE 2000 SP3.  The vendor indicates that users of Windows Server 2003 users should use the Windows Update function.

Microsoft plans to include this fix in SQL Server 2000 SP4 and Windows Server 2003 SP1.

A reboot is required in most cases.

This update supersedes MS02-061.

Microsoft plans to issue Knowledge Base article 815495 regarding this issue, to be available shortly on the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://support.microsoft.com/?kbid=815495

Title: mSQL Database Format String Flaw Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A format string vulnerability was reported in Mini SQL (mSQL).  A remote user can obtain root group privileges on the target system.
Packetstorm posted an exploit by lucipher & The Itch of the Netric Security Team that reportedly triggers a format string flaw in Mini SQL (mSQL) to give the remote user 'root' group privileges on the target system.  It appears that the remote user must first be authenticated.

The code attempts to bind a root (group) shell to port 26112.

The code appears to send an exploit string of the following format:

[formatstring characters][addresses][shell code][os-specific addresses]

The exploit code is available at:

http://packetstorm.linuxsecurity.com/0307-exploits/msqlex.c
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target system with root group privileges.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Oracle Database EXTPROC Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Authenticated Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): Oracle9i Release 2; Oracle9i Release 1; Oracle8i (8.1.x   all releases)
Description:
Several buffer overflow vulnerabilities were reported in the Oracle Database in the EXTPROC application.  A remote authenticated user may be able to execute arbitrary code.
Oracle reported that a remote authenticated user with 'CREATE LIBRARY' or 'CREATE ANY LIBRARY' privileges can trigger the overflow and execute arbitrary code.  David Litchfield reports that authentication is not required.

Oracle notes that this flaw is similar to that reported in Oracle Security Alert 29 (http://otn.oracle.com/deploy/security/pdf/plsextproc_alert.pdf).

Oracle credits David Litchfield and Chris Anley, of Next Generation Security Software Ltd., with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has released the Oracle9i Database Release 2, Version 9.2.0.4 patchset.  Some patches are also available for versions 9.2.0.2 and 9.2.0.3.  A full Patch Availability Matrix is provided in the Oracle Security Alert.

Patches are available at:

http://metalink.oracle.com
Underlying OS Comments: Solaris, AIX, NT, 2000, XP, HP-UX, Tru64, Linux, OpenVMS, MVS
