Solution:
The vendor has released a cumulative patch.


For Microsoft SQL Server 7.0:

http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;en-us;Q327068&sd=tech

For Microsoft SQL Server 2000:

http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;en-us;Q316333&sd=tech

Microsoft reports that the SQL Server 7.0 patch can be installed on SQL Server 7.0 SP4 and the SQL Server 2000 patch can be installed on SQL Server 2000 SP2.

Microsoft plans to include the fix for this issue in SQL Server 2000 SP4.

Please read the Microsoft bulletin for some important caveats regarding some areas that this cumulative patch does not include.

This patch supersedes the one provided in Microsoft Security Bulletin MS02-043.

Microsoft plans to issue Knowledge Base article Q316333 regarding this issue, to be available shortly on the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://support.microsoft.com/?scid=fh;en-us;kbhowto

Title: Borland InterBase 'gds_lock_mgr' Temporary File Security Hole Gives Local Users Root Access
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Borland InterBase gds_lock_mgr database component.  A local user can write arbitrary code to certain files with root privileges.
A local user can create a symbolic link from an arbitrary file (for example, a backdoor xinetd process) to a specially named temporary file used by InterBase.  Then, the local user can execute gds_lock_mgr to cause the arbitrary symlink file to be created with the privileges of gds_lock_mgr.  Arbitrary code can then be written to the file and executed when the host is rebooted.

According to the report, 'gds_lock_mgr' is configured with set user id (setuid) root privileges.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.

[Editor's note:  As noted in this report, the vulnerability described in this alert is different than the gds_lock_mgr buffer overflow that was reported in June 2002.]
Impact': A local user can write to arbitrary files with root privileges to gain root access on the system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Microsoft Visual FoxPro Filename Processing Bug Lets Remote Users Create HTML That Will Cause Arbitrary Code to Be Executed When the HTML is Loaded
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Microsoft Visual FoxPro.  A remote user could create HTML that, when loaded, will cause the FoxPro application to launch and execute arbitrary code on the target user's system.
Microsoft reports that Visual FoxPro 6.0 fails to perform registration with Internet Explorer (IE).  So, when a target user loads HTML that references a Visual FoxPro application (a '.app' file), it is possible that the typical warning dialog process that IE presents to the target user may be bypassed and the FoxPro application could be started.  If a remote user creates a specially crafted filename for the '.app' file, FoxPro may start and execute the application.  This is apparently due to a flaw in the way Visual FoxPro 6.0 evaluates application filenames.

A malicious application could query FoxPro databases and issue operating system commands in the security context of the target user.

A target user is reportedly to be vulnerable only is Visual FoxPro application or the runtime version of Visual FoxPro is installed.  Note that some third-party products may install the Visual FoxPro 6.0 runtime.

The vendor indicats that you can determine whether the Visual FoxPro 6.0 runtime is present on your system by searching for any of the following files on your system: vfp6r.dll, vfp6t.dll, or vfp6run.exe. If any of these files are present, Visual FoxPro 6.0 is installed on your system and your system is affected.

Version 7.0 is reportedly not affected.

Microsoft credits Cristobal Bielza and Juan Carlos G. Cuartango from Instituto Seguridad Internet (http://www.instisec.com) for reporting this bug.
Impact': A remote user can cause arbitrary FoxPro commands and operating system commands to be executed on the target user's system.  The commands will run with the privileges of the target user.
Solution:
The vendor has released a patch for Microsoft Visual FoxPro 6.0, available at:

http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=42297

This patch can reportedly be installed on systems running Visual FoxPro 6.0. There are no service pack requirements.

Microsoft plans to issue Knowledge Base article Q326568 regarding this issue, to be available shortly on the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://support.microsoft.com/?scid=fh;en-us;kbhowto

Microsoft also indicates that you can mitigate the impact of this flaw by manually registering Visual FoxPro 6.0 with Internet Explorer using the following procedure:

   1. Open Control Panel
   2. Select "Tools", then "Folder Options"
   3. Click the "File Types" tab
   4. In the scroll box titled "Registered File Types", select the "APP" extension. (If this extension is not present in the list, it means you don't have Visual FoxPro installed).
   5. Click on "Advanced"
   6. Select "Confirm open after downloading".
   7. Hit OK to close the Edit File Type dialogue
   8. Hit OK to close the File Options dialogue
   9. Close Control Panel

Title: (Windows .NET Server is Also Affected) Re: Microsoft Desktop Engine (MSDE) Extended Stored Procedures May Let Local Users Execute Commands With Database Administrator Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in some Microsoft Desktop Engine (MSDE) extended stored procedures.  A local user may be able to execute stored procedures on the database with administrator privileges.
It is reported that some Microsoft-provided extended stored procedures have the ability to reconnect to the database as the SQL Server service account and can be executed by unprivileged users.

A local user could execute a specially crafted database query that calls one of the vulnerable extended store procedures. 

Microsoft credits David Litchfield of Next Generation Security Software Ltd. for reporting these issues and Chip Andrews of www.sqlsecurity.com and Timothy Mullen for reporting additional information on these issues.
Impact': A user could add, change or delete data in the database, reconfigure the operating system, install new software, or reformat the hard drive.
Solution:
Microsoft has released a cumulative patch for SQL Server (of which MSDE is a component).  According to NGSSoftware, Windows .NET Server is affected by this vulnerability.

[Editor's note: Microsoft did not indicate how to patch MSDE and not SQL Server.]

Microsoft SQL Server 7.0:

http://www.microsoft.com/Release.asp?ReleaseID=Q327068

Microsoft SQL Server 2000:

http://www.microsoft.com/Release.asp?ReleaseID=Q316333

The SQL Server 7.0 patch can be installed on systems running SQL Server 7.0 SP4. The SQL Server 2000 patch can be installed on systems running SQL Server 2000 SP2.

The fix for this issue will be included in SQL Server 2000 SP3.

This patch does not include the functionality of the Killpwd tool provided in Microsoft Security Bulletin MS02-035.

The patch does not supersede any previously released patches for MDAC or OLAP under SQL Server 2000. At the time of the Microsoft bulletin, these patches include the ones discussed in:

Microsoft Security Bulletin MS00-092
Microsoft Security Bulletin MS01-041
Microsoft Security Bulletin MS02-030

Microsoft notes that the process for installing the patch varies somewhat depending on the specific configuration of the server, so system administrators should ensure that they read the Readme.txt file in the patch package to ensure the patch is installed correctly.

Microsoft plans to issued Knowledge Base articles Q327068 and Q316333 regarding this issue, to be available shortly on the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://support.microsoft.com/?scid=fh;en-us;k bhowto

Title: (A User Reports Additional Overflows That Are Fixed) Re: Microsoft SQL Server Buffer Overflow in Database Consistency Checker May Let Remote Authenticated Users Execute Arbitrary Code with the Privileges of the Database Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Microsoft reported that a buffer overflow may allow a local user or remote authenticated user to execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the database service.  Also, an input validation flaw in two stored procedures may allow a local user or remote authenticated user to execute arbitrary operating system commands.
A buffer overflow was reported in the processing of user-supplied input in some Database Consistency Checkers (DBCCs) used for database maintenance.  A local user or remote authenticated user with 'db_owner' or 'db_ddladmin' privileges could cause arbitrary code to be executed in the security context of the SQL Server service.  By default, this is usually a Domain User account.  This could give the user complete control over the database but not over the operating system itself.  The user could also cause the SQL service to crash.

An SQL injection flaw in two stored procedures used for database replication may allow certain users to execute operating system commands on the server.  Due to a permissions error, one of the stored procedures can be run by any local or remote authenticated user.  According to the report, this vulnerability can only be exploited if the administrator has enabled the SQL Server Agent Proxy account. By default, this account is disabled.  The operating system commands would be executed with the privileges of the SQL Server Agent Proxy account (by default, these are Domain User privileges).

Microsoft reports that SQL Server 7.0 is not affected.

Microsoft credits Cesar Cerrudo for reporting this issue.
Impact': A local user or remote authenticated user could cause the database service to crash or could execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the database service.  A local user or remote authenticated user could execute arbitrary operating system commands with the privileges of the SQL Server Agent Proxy account.
Solution:
A user reports that there are two additional buffer overflows that are not mentioned in the original report or the Microsoft advisory. They are:

1) DBCC buffer(master, long string)

2) DBCC DBCC procbuf(master,'longstring',1,0)

According to the report, Microsoft's patch corrects these overflow conditions.

Microsoft has released a cumulative patch, available at:

http://support.microsoft.com/support/misc/kblookup.asp?id=Q316333

For more information on the patch or the originally reported vulnerabilities, see the Message History.

Title: PostgreSQL Database Buffer Overflow in 'cash_words' Function May Let Local Users Obtain Elevated Privileges on the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the PostgreSQL database.  A local user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed with the privileges of the database user account.
Mordred Labs issued an advisory warning that there is a stack based buffer overflow in cash_words() function.  A local user may be able to trigger the overflow to execute arbitrary code on the system.

A demonstration exploit transcript is provided:

psql> select cash_words('-700000000000000000000000000000');
pgReadData() -- backend closed the channel unexpectedly.
	.... ....
The connection to the server was lost...
Impact': A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the database user.  If a remote user can submit arbitrary queries or queries using the affected function, then this vulanerability may potentially be exploited by a remote user.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (7.2.1), available at:

http://www.postgresql.org/

Title: Microsoft Desktop Engine (MSDE) Extended Stored Procedures May Let Local Users Execute Commands With Database Administrator Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in some Microsoft Desktop Engine (MSDE) extended stored procedures.  A local user may be able to execute stored procedures on the database with administrator privileges.
It is reported that some Microsoft-provided extended stored procedures have the ability to reconnect to the database as the SQL Server service account and can be executed by unprivileged users.

A local user could execute a specially crafted database query that calls one of the vulnerable extended store procedures. 

Microsoft credits David Litchfield of Next Generation Security Software Ltd. for reporting these issues and Chip Andrews of www.sqlsecurity.com and Timothy Mullen for reporting additional information on these issues.
Impact': A user could add, change or delete data in the database, reconfigure the operating system, install new software, or reformat the hard drive.
Solution:
Microsoft has released a cumulative patch for SQL Server (of which MSDE is a component).

[Editor's note:  Microsoft did not indicate how to patch MSDE and not SQL Server.]

Microsoft SQL Server 7.0:

http://www.microsoft.com/Release.asp?ReleaseID=Q327068

Microsoft SQL Server 2000:

http://www.microsoft.com/Release.asp?ReleaseID=Q316333

The SQL Server 7.0 patch can be installed on systems running SQL Server 7.0 SP4.  The SQL Server 2000 patch can be installed on systems running SQL Server 2000 SP2.

The fix for this issue will be included in SQL Server 2000 SP3.

This patch does not include the functionality of the Killpwd tool provided in Microsoft Security Bulletin MS02-035.

The patch does not supersede any previously released patches for MDAC or OLAP under SQL Server 2000. At the time of the Microsoft bulletin, these patches include the ones discussed in:

Microsoft Security Bulletin MS00-092
Microsoft Security Bulletin MS01-041
Microsoft Security Bulletin MS02-030

Microsoft notes that the process for installing the patch varies somewhat depending on the specific configuration of the server, so system administrators should ensure that they read the Readme.txt file in the patch package to ensure the patch is installed correctly.

Microsoft plans to issued Knowledge Base articles Q327068 and Q316333 regarding this issue, to be available shortly on the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://support.microsoft.com/?scid=fh;en-us;kbhowto

Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:

It is reported that some Microsoft-provided extended stored procedures have the ability to reconnect to the database as the SQL Server service account and can be executed by unprivileged users.

Microsoft Security Bulletin MS00-092
Microsoft Security Bulletin MS01-041
Microsoft Security Bulletin MS02-030

Microsoft notes that the process for installing the patch varies somewhat depending on the specific configuration of the server, so system administrators should ensure that they read the Readme.txt file in the patch package to ensure the patch is installed correctly.

Microsoft plans to issued Knowledge Base articles Q327068 and Q316333 regarding this issue, to be available shortly on the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://support.microsoft.com/?scid=fh;en-us;kbhowto

Title: Oracle Enterprise Manager Web Service Component of Oracle 9i Application Server Discloses the Web Cache Administrator Password to Local Users
Description:
An authentication information disclosure vulnerability was reported in the Oracle Web Cache for the Oracle 9i Application Server.  A local user can obtain the Web Cache administrator password.
It is reported that the Oracle Enterprise Manager Web site provided with the Oracle9i Application Server provides a web-based administration interface to the Web Cache.  An unencrypted copy of the Web Cache administrator password is used to start this web interface.  A local user could gain access to the Web cache administrator password.
Impact': A local user could obtain the Web Cache administrator password.
Solution:
Oracle reports that there is no patch for this potential security vulnerability.  However, Oracle strongly encourages customers to take the following measures:

1. Edit the file, $ORACLE_HOME/sysman/emd/targets.xml.  Replace the line:

<Property NAME="authpwd" VALUE="administrator"/>

with the following:

<Property NAME="authpwd" VALUE="administrator" ENCRYPTED="FALSE" />

(Note that  FALSE  is all capital letters.)

2. Restart the Oracle Enterprise Manager web site or execute "emctl reload" at the command prompt.

Note that restarting (or reloading) the OEM web site changes the line in targets.xml to:

<Property NAME="authpwd" VALUE="xxxx" ENCRYPTED="TRUE" />

(targets.xml is a dynamic file containing field values that may change upon reloading or restarting as is the case above.)

The vulnerability will be fixed by default in a future release of Oracle9i Application  Server.

Title: Oracle 9i Database Input Validation Bugs in the Oracle Net Listener Lets Remote Authenticated Users Crash the Listener, Denying Service to Database Users
Description:
Oracle reported two vulnerabilities affecting the Oracle Net Listener for the Oracle 9i database server.  A remote authenticated user may be able to cause the database Listener component to crash in certain situations, denying database access to other users.
It is reported that an authenticated remote user can modify the Oracle Net Listener s configuration file (listener.ora) to include a specially crafted format string.  The next time the Listener control utility (LSNRCTL) is used to start up the Listener, the Listener may crash.

An Oracle database administrator (DBA) can reportedly supply specially crafted input containing format strings to the Oracle Net Listener control utility (LSNRCTL) so that the Listener will crash when started.
Impact': A remote authenticate user may be able to cause denial of service conditions on the database.
Solution:
Oracle has issued a patch (under the base bug number 2395416).  Patches are available from Oracle Worldwide Support Services web site, Metalink (http://metalink.oracle.com). Activate the  Patches  button to get to the patches Web page. Enter bug Number 2395416 as indicated above and activate the  Submit  button.

In addition to available patches, Oracle strongly urges customers to take the following steps to address the vulnerabilities identified above.

1. Configure listener password to prevent unauthorized users from administering the listener.

Alternatively, set ADMIN_RESTRICTIONS_listener_name=ON in listener.ora to completely disable the runtime modification of listener s configuration parameters.

2. Set appropriate Operating System directory and file permissions on the Listener configuration file, listener.ora.

For example:

Unix: $ chmod 600 $ORACLE_HOME/network/admin/listener.ora
Windows: File properties > Security > Permissions  

3. Do not attempt to start an Oracle Net Listener with an invalid name.

Title: Oracle9i Debugging Flaw in SQL*NET Listener Lets Remote Users Crash the Database Listener and Deny Service to Database Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Oracle 9i.  A remote user can cause the SQL*NET listener to crash.
ISS X-Force reported that a remote user can send a specially crafted request to an Oracle9i SQL*NET listener to cause it to fail.  The listerner must be manually restarted to return the database to normal operations.
Impact': A remote user can cause the SQL*NET listener to crash, causing a denial of service condition with the database.
Solution:
The vendor has released a patch and has assigned this flaw bug number 2467947. Future releases of the Oracle Database server will contain the fix by default.

Download currently available patches from Oracle Worldwide Support Services web site, Metalink, (http://metalink.oracle.com). Activate the  Patches  button to get to the patches Web page. Enter Bug Number 2467947 as indicated above and activate the  Submit  button.

Title: IBM U2 UniVerse Database May Allow Remote Users to Crash the Server By Making Invalid Queries
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in IBM's U2 UniVerse database.  A remote user may be able to cause the server to crash by making an invalid query.
A remote user can reportedly make a query accessing UV/ODBC to attempt to make an invalid link between tables to cause the server to crash, locking the line and the file.

The report indicates that this has been demonstrated using CrystalReports to make queries.
Impact': A remote user can reportedly cause the database service to crash.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report indicated that you can reboot the server to return the system to normal operations.

Title: Microsoft SQL Server MDAC Function Buffer Overflow May Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code to Gain Full Control Over the Database
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Microsoft Data Access Components (MDAC) software for Microsoft SQL Server.  A remote user may be able to execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the database server.
The vulnerability reportedly resides in the Transact-SQL (T-SQL) OpenRowSet command support in MDAC.  A remote user with the ability to load and execute a database query can submit a specially crafted and 'extremely long' parameter with a call to OpenRowSet() to trigger the buffer overflow.  This may cause the SQL Server to crash or execute arbitrary code.  

The code would most likely run with Domain User privileges, giving the remote user full control over the database, as the default configuration of SQL Server is to run as a Domain User.  However, in some alternate configurations, the code may run with administrative privileges, giving the remote user full control over the operating system.

Microsoft reports that, although MDAC ships with a variety of Windows software, only SQL Server exposes the vulnerability.

Microsoft credits David Litchfield of Next Generation Security Software Ltd. with reporting the flaw.
Impact': A remote user with the ability to load and execute database queries may be able to cause the database service to crash or arbitrary code to be executed on the system with the privileges of the database server.
Solution:
The vendor has issued patches:

MDAC 2.5:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=41076

MDAC 2.6:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=41077

MDAC 2.7:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=41072

The vendor reports that MDAC 2.5 patch can be installed on systems using MDAC 2.5 SP2, the MDAC 2.6 patch can be installed on systems using MDAC 2.6 SP2, and the MDAC 2.7 patch can be installed on systems using MDAC 2.7 Gold.

Microsoft adds that this fix will be included in MDAC 2.5 SP3, MDAC 2.6 SP3, and MDAC 2.7 SP1.

To determine which version of MDAC is on the system, refer to the HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\DataAccess registry key. The 'FullInstallVer' key provides a value of the form x.xx.yyyy.y, where x.xx is the version number (e.g., if the FullInstallVer value were 2.70.7713.0, it would mean that MDAC 2.7 is installed on the system).

Or, you can right click on C:\Program Files\Common Files\System\ado\msado15.dll, select Properties, and then refer to the Version information. The version information has the same format as that of the FullInstallVer value -- x.xx.yyyy.y, where x.xx is the version number.

Microsoft plans to issued Knowledge Base article Q326573 regarding this issue, to be available shortly at the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://search.support.microsoft.com/kb/c.asp?SD=SO&LN=EN-US

Title: Microsoft Data Engine (MSDE) Buffer Overflow in Database Consistency Checker May Let Remote Authenticated Users Execute Arbitrary Code with the Privileges of the Database Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Microsoft reported that a buffer overflow may allow a local user or remote authenticated user to execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the database service.  Also, an input validation flaw in two stored procedures may allow a local user or remote authenticated user to execute arbitrary operating system commands.
A buffer overflow was reported in the processing of user-supplied input in some Database Consistency Checkers (DBCCs) used for database maintenance.  A local user or remote authenticated user with 'db_owner' or 'db_ddladmin' privileges could cause arbitrary code to be executed in the security context of the MSDE service.  By default, this is usually a Domain User account.  This could give the user complete control over the database but not over the operating system itself.  The user could also cause the SQL service to crash.

An SQL injection flaw in two stored procedures used for database replication may allow certain users to execute operating system commands on the server.  Due to a permissions error, one of the stored procedures can be run by any local or remote authenticated user.  According to the report, this vulnerability can only be exploited if the administrator has enabled the SQL Server Agent Proxy account. By default, this account is disabled.  The operating system commands would be executed with the privileges of the SQL Server Agent Proxy account (by default, these are Domain User privileges).

Microsoft reports that SQL Server 7.0 is not affected.

Microsoft credits Cesar Cerrudo for reporting this issue.
Impact': A local user or remote authenticated user could cause the database service to crash or could execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the database service.  A local user or remote authenticated user could execute arbitrary operating system commands with the privileges of the SQL Server Agent Proxy account.
Solution:
Microsoft has released a cumulative patch, available at:

http://support.microsoft.com/support/misc/kblookup.asp?id=Q316333

This patch can only be installed on systems running SQL Server 2000 SP2.  The fix will reportedly will be included in SQL Server 2000 SP3.  This cumulative patch supersedes the cumulative patch described in Microsoft Security Bulletin MS02-034.  However, Microsoft warns that this patch, by itself, is not enough to secure a SQL Server installation.  Please see the original Microsoft advisory (available at the Vendor URL) for some important caveats regarding areas that this cumulative patch does not cover.

Microsoft plans to issue Knowledge Base article Q316333 regarding this issue, to be available shortly at the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://search.support.microsoft.com/kb/c.asp?SD=SO&LN=EN-US

Title: Microsoft SQL Server Buffer Overflow in Database Consistency Checker May Let Remote Authenticated Users Execute Arbitrary Code with the Privileges of the Database Service
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Microsoft reported that a buffer overflow may allow a local user or remote authenticated user to execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the database service.  Also, an input validation flaw in two stored procedures may allow a local user or remote authenticated user to execute arbitrary operating system commands.
A buffer overflow was reported in the processing of user-supplied input in some Database Consistency Checkers (DBCCs) used for database maintenance.  A local user or remote authenticated user with 'db_owner' or 'db_ddladmin' privileges could cause arbitrary code to be executed in the security context of the SQL Server service.  By default, this is usually a Domain User account.  This could give the user complete control over the database but not over the operating system itself.  The user could also cause the SQL service to crash.

An SQL injection flaw in two stored procedures used for database replication may allow certain users to execute operating system commands on the server.  Due to a permissions error, one of the stored procedures can be run by any local or remote authenticated user.  According to the report, this vulnerability can only be exploited if the administrator has enabled the SQL Server Agent Proxy account. By default, this account is disabled.  The operating system commands would be executed with the privileges of the SQL Server Agent Proxy account (by default, these are Domain User privileges).

Microsoft reports that SQL Server 7.0 is not affected.

Microsoft credits Cesar Cerrudo for reporting this issue.
Impact': A local user or remote authenticated user could cause the database service to crash or could execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the database service.  A local user or remote authenticated user could execute arbitrary operating system commands with the privileges of the SQL Server Agent Proxy account.
Solution:
Microsoft has released a cumulative patch, available at:

http://support.microsoft.com/support/misc/kblookup.asp?id=Q316333

This patch can only be installed on systems running SQL Server 2000 SP2.  The fix will reportedly will be included in SQL Server 2000 SP3.  This cumulative patch supersedes the cumulative patch described in Microsoft Security Bulletin MS02-034.  However, Microsoft warns that this patch, by itself, is not enough to secure a SQL Server installation.  Please see the original Microsoft advisory (available at the Vendor URL) for some important caveats regarding areas that this cumulative patch does not cover.

Microsoft plans to issue Knowledge Base article Q316333 regarding this issue, to be available shortly at the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://search.support.microsoft.com/kb/c.asp?SD=SO&LN=EN-US

Title: Microsoft SQL Server Resolution Service Buffer Overflows Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code with the Privileges of the SQL Service
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Microsoft reported two buffer overflow vulnerabilities and one denial of service vulnerability in SQL Server 2000.  A remote user could execute arbitrary code on the server with the privileges of the database service.  A remote user could also cause system performance to be degraded.
A remote user can reportedly send a specially crafted packet to the SQL Server 2000 Resolution Service on UDP port 1434 to trigger one of two overflows, a heap overflow or a stack overflow.  This could cause the SQL Server service to crash, or it could cause arbitrary code to be executed in the security context of the SQL Server service.  By default, this service runs as a Domain User.

A remote user also could trigger a packet storm between two servers by sending a spoofed keep-alive packet to the Resolution Service.  As a result, the target SQL Server 2000 will respond with the same information.  If the original packet was crafted to appear to have originated from another SQL Server 2000 system, the two systems could reportedly enter a never-ending cycle of keep-alive packet exchanges, causing excessive resources to be consumed on both systems.

Microsoft credits David Litchfield of Next Generation Security Software Ltd. for reporting these issues.
Impact': A remote user could cause arbitrary code to be executed on the system with the privileges of the SQL Server service, giving the remote user full control over the database.  A remote user could cause performance on two SQL Server hosts to become degraded.
Solution:
Microsoft has released a patch for Microsoft SQL Server 2000, available at:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=40602

This patch can reportedly be installed on systems running SQL Server 2000 SP2.

Microsoft reports that this fix will be included in SQL Server 2000 SP3.

Microsoft plans to issue Knowledge Base article Q323875 regarding this issue, to be available shortly on the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://search.support.microsoft.com/kb/c.asp?SD=SO&LN=EN-US

Title: Oracle Reports Server Discloses System Information to Remote Users
Description:
An information disclosure vulnerability was reported in Oracle Reports Server.  A remote user can obtain information about the system.
AngryPacket Security issued an advisory warning that a remote user can obtain various details about the system, including the location physical path installation directory and version numbers, by using the rwcgi60 script.

Some demonstration exploit URLs are provided.

http://some.site.com/cgi-bin/rwcgi60
http://some.site.com/cgi-bin/rwcgi60/showenv


Some of the typical variables that can be viewed are shown below:

# PATH D:\ORACLE\iSuites\Apache\fastcg;D:\ORACLE\806\jdk\bin
# ORACLE_HOME D:\ORACLE\806
# REPORTS60_PATH D:\WEB_REPORTS
# REPORTS60_TMP D:\ORACLE\806\REPORT60\TMP

Some of the typical version number information that can be viewed is shown below:

# Oracle Reports Server CGI60 version 6.0, a Win32 executable
# Oracle_Web_Listener/4.0.7.0.0 Enterprise Edition

Some additional information that can be viewed is shown below:

# Stdin is empty.
# CGI Command Line is used
# main.argv[0] d:\oracle\806\tools\web60\cgi\rwcgi60.EXE

For the original advisory, see the AngryPacket Security web site at:

http://sec.angrypacket.com

AngryPacket credits skp (of AngryPacket security group) with discovering the bug.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can obtain information about the system, such as product version numbers and the physical installation path.
Solution: According to the report, Oracle note 133957.1 ("Restricting Access to the Reports Server Environment and Output") describes configuration methods to mitigate the vulnerability.

Title: Microsoft SQL Server Install Process May Disclose Sensitive Passwords to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Microsoft SQL Server 7.0 (including MSDE 1.0) and SQL Server 2000.  During installation, the 'sa' account password may be stored in clear text in the 'setup.iss' file and also written to a log file
According to the report, the passwords are stored in clear text in versions prior to SQL Server 7.0 SP4.  In more recent versions, the passwords are encrypted before storage, but are weakly encrypted.

The log file created during installation will reportedly include any passwords that had been stored in the setup.iss file.

The 'setup.iss' file and the log file both remain on the server after the installation is complete and are, in general, readable by all users on the server.

Microsoft credits Cesar Cerrudo for reporting this bug.
Impact': A local user may be able to read certain files to view the 'sa' account passwords or other domain passwords.
Solution:
Microsoft has issued a special utility (KillPwd) to correct this vulnerability.

For Microsoft SQL 7, MSDE 1.0, and Microsoft SQL Server 2000:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=40205

This utility can be run on systems with:

- SQL Server 7.0 Gold, SP1, SP2, SP3, or SP4
- MSDE 1.0
- SQL Server 2000 Gold, SP1, or SP2

Microsoft plans to include the fix for this issue in SQL Server 7.0 SP5 and SQL Server 2000 SP3.

The KillPwd tool provided in this bulletin supersedes the one previously provided as part of Microsoft Security Bulletin MS00-035.

Microsoft plans to issue Knowledge Base article Q263968 regarding this bug, to be available shortly on the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://search.support.microsoft.com/kb/c.asp?SD=SO&LN=EN-US

Title: (Microsoft Issues Fix) Re: Microsoft SQL Server Buffer Overflow in 'pwdencrypt()' Function May Let Remote Authorized Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in Microsoft SQL Server 2000.  An authorized remote user can cause the SQL Server service to crash and may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed on the system.
It is reported that there is a buffer/heap overflow in the built-in hashing function pwdencrypt().  The following demonstration exploit code is provided:

SELECT pwdencrypt(REPLICATE('A',353))

According to the report, the number of characters required to trigger the overflow may be larger on some systems.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can cause the SQL service to crash.  A remote user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed by the SQL Server process.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following patches.  These are cumulative security patches.

Microsoft SQL Server 2000:

http://support.microsoft.com/support/misc/kblookup.asp?id=Q316333

This patch supercedes the one referenced in MS02-020.

The SQL Server 2000 patch can be installed on systems running SQL Server 2000 SP2.  The vendor plans to include the fix for these bugs in SQL Server 2000 SP3.

Microsoft plans to issue a Knowledge Base article (Q316333) regarding this issue, to be available shortly at the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://search.support.microsoft.com/kb/c.asp?SD=SO&LN=EN-US

Title: Microsoft SQL Server Desktop Engine (MSDE) Buffer Overflow and Access Control Bug May Let Remote Authorized Users Execute Code with Elevated Privileges, Possibly Including Local System Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in Microsoft SQL Server Desktop Engine (MSDE).  One bug is a buffer overflow vulnerability and one is an access control vulnerability.  A remote authorized user could execute arbitrary code on the server with the privileges of the SQL Server account or could obtain elevated privileges.
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in an SQL Server procedure that is used to bulk-insert data into database tables.  A remote authorized user could trigger this buffer overflow to execute arbitrary code on the system with the privileges of the SQL Server account.  According to the report, only 'Bulk Admins' and full administrators can load and run the types of queries that invoke the vulnerable procedure.

An access control vulnerability was reported for the registry key used to store SQL Server service account information.  The system does not apply the proper permissions to this key.  A remote authorized user could gain elevated privileges, possibly including System level privileges, by causing the SQL Server service to write to the registry and specify a different service account (such as LocalSystem).  Then, the next time the SQL Server Service starts, the SQL Server would run in a different, more privileged account than was originally granted by the system administrator.  To exploit this, the user must have the ability to load and run queries on the system and must have been granted 'xp_regwrite' execute permissions.

SQL Server 7 is not affected by these vulnerabilities, according to Microsoft.

Microsoft credits Cesar Cerrudo and David Litchfield with reporting the "Unchecked Buffer in Bulk Update Procedure" bug.
Impact': A remote authorized user may be able to execute arbitrary code on the system with the privileges of the SQL Server account.  A remote authorized user with 'xp_regwrite' execute permissions may be able to change the SQL Server privileges to LocalSystem privileges and then run procedures with LocalSystem privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following patches.  These are cumulative security patches.

Microsoft SQL Server 2000:

http://support.microsoft.com/support/misc/kblookup.asp?id=Q316333

This patch supercedes the one referenced in MS02-020.

The SQL Server 2000 patch can be installed on systems running SQL Server 2000 SP2.  The vendor plans to include the fix for these bugs in SQL Server 2000 SP3.

Microsoft plans to issue a Knowledge Base article (Q316333) regarding this issue, to be available shortly at the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://search.support.microsoft.com/kb/c.asp?SD=SO&LN=EN-US

Title: Microsoft SQL Server Buffer Overflow and Access Control Bug May Let Remote Authorized Users Execute Code with Elevated Privileges, Possibly Including Local System Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in Microsoft SQL Server and Microsoft SQL Server Desktop Engine (MSDE).  One bug is a buffer overflow vulnerability and one is an access control vulnerability.  A remote authorized user could execute arbitrary code on the server with the privileges of the SQL Server account or could obtain elevated privileges.
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in an SQL Server procedure that is used to bulk-insert data into database tables.  A remote authorized user could trigger this buffer overflow to execute arbitrary code on the system with the privileges of the SQL Server account.  According to the report, only 'Bulk Admins' and full administrators can load and run the types of queries that invoke the vulnerable procedure.

An access control vulnerability was reported for the registry key used to store SQL Server service account information.  The system does not apply the proper permissions to this key.  A remote authorized user could gain elevated privileges, possibly including System level privileges, by causing the SQL Server service to write to the registry and specify a different service account (such as LocalSystem).  Then, the next time the SQL Server Service starts, the SQL Server would run in a different, more privileged account than was originally granted by the system administrator.  To exploit this, the user must have the ability to load and run queries on the system and must have been granted 'xp_regwrite' execute permissions.

SQL Server 7 is not affected by these vulnerabilities, according to Microsoft.

Microsoft credits Cesar Cerrudo and David Litchfield with reporting the "Unchecked Buffer in Bulk Update Procedure" bug.
Impact': A remote authorized user may be able to execute arbitrary code on the system with the privileges of the SQL Server account.  A remote authorized user with 'xp_regwrite' execute permissions may be able to change the SQL Server privileges to LocalSystem privileges and then run procedures with LocalSystem privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following patches.  These are cumulative security patches.

Microsoft SQL Server 2000:

http://support.microsoft.com/support/misc/kblookup.asp?id=Q316333

This patch supercedes the one referenced in MS02-020.

The SQL Server 2000 patch can be installed on systems running SQL Server 2000 SP2.  The vendor plans to include the fix for these bugs in SQL Server 2000 SP3.

Microsoft plans to issue a Knowledge Base article (Q316333) regarding this issue, to be available shortly at the Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://search.support.microsoft.com/kb/c.asp?SD=SO&LN=EN-US

Title: Microsoft SQL Server 2000 Buffer Overflow in OpenDataSource() Function May Let Remote Users Gain SYSTEM Privileges on the Server
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in Microsoft SQL Server 2000.  A remote user may be able to gain privileges on the system, possibly including SYSTEM level privileges.
NGSSoftware issued a security advisory warning of a buffer overflow in Microsoft SQL Server 2000.  The flaw is reported to be in the OpenDataSource function when combined with Microsoft Jet.  The bug is in Microsoft Jet and also affects products other than Microsoft SQL Server 2000, including Microsoft Access.

A remote user can send a specially crafted SQL query using the OpenDataSource() function to trigger a buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code on the system.

In the default configuration of Microsoft SQL Server, the server apparently runs with SYSTEM privileges.

This flaw can be exploted via a web browser if SQL Server is being used in a certain manner by a web application.

A demonstration exploit is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the server to obtain up to SYSTEM level privileges.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.  The fix is for Microsoft Jet and is described in the following Microsoft Knowledge Base article:

http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;en-us;q282010

For Windows 2000, the fix information is available at:

http://www.microsoft.com/windows2000/downloads/recommended/q282010/default.asp

Title: Borland InterBase Buffer Overflow May Be Triggered By Local Users to Gain Root Access
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in several components of Borland's InterBase database.  A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with root privileges to gain root access on the system.
Strategic Reconnaissance Team issued a security advisory warning of flaws in the version of InterBase that is provided with Mandrake 7.2 (interbase-6.0-1.i386.rpm).  This flaw may also affect other distributions, but that has not been confirmed.

A local user can set the enivornment variable "INTERBASE" with a value that will cause a malloc() overflow.  A demonstration exploit transcript is provided:

[dotslash@ghetto dotslash]$ export INTERBASE=`perl -e 'print "A" x 500'`
[dotslash@ghetto dotslash]$ /usr/local/interbase/bin/gds_drop
Segmentation fault

The advisory states that the following binaries that are configured with set user id (suid) root privileges may be exploitable:

/usr/local/interbase/bin/gds_drop
/usr/local/interbase/bin/gds_inet_server
/usr/local/interbase/bin/gds_lock_mgr 

The advisory also notes that the current version (6.5) was not tested, so it is not known whether the current version is affected or not.

Some demonstration exploit code is provided in the Source Message.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with root privileges, giving the user root access on the system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.
Underlying OS Comments: Only Linux Mandrake is confirmed to have the flaw, but other systems may be affected

Title: Microsoft SQL Server Buffer Overflow in 'pwdencrypt()' Function May Let Remote Authorized Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in Microsoft SQL Server 2000.  An authorized remote user can cause the SQL Server service to crash and may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed on the system.
It is reported that there is a buffer/heap overflow in the built-in hashing function pwdencrypt().  The following demonstration exploit code is provided:

SELECT pwdencrypt(REPLICATE('A',353))

According to the report, the number of characters required to trigger the overflow may be larger on some systems.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can cause the SQL service to crash.  A remote user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed by the SQL Server process.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The vendor is reportedly working on a patch.

Title: Microsoft SQLXML Component of Microsoft SQL Server 2000 Contains an Input Validation Flaw in an XML SQL Tag That Allows Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Microsoft reported a vulnerability in Microsoft SQLXML, a component of Microsoft SQL Server 2000.  A remote user can create a specially crafted session to cause scripts to run on another user's system in the Security Zone associated with the Internet Information Server (IIS) web server running the SQLXML HTTP components.
The vulnerability is due to the insufficient validation of the 'ROOT' XML element in an XML SQL query.

A remote user can create an HTML link that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser.  The HTML link can consist of an XML SQL query that includes scripting code within the 'ROOT' element.  When this element is included in a query, the web server will reportedly return the scripting code in the web server's reply.  The script would originate from the web server and would run in the security zone of that web server.

Users that have permissions to query a vulnerable SQL server may be affected.  A remote user must know the name of the vulnerble SQL server and other information to exploit the bug.

Microsoft credits Matt Moore of Westpoint Ltd. with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A remote user could create an HTML link that, when loaded by the target user, would cause arbitrary scripting to be executed by the target user's browser.  The code would run in the security context of the IIS/SQL web site and would be able to access the target user's cookies associated with that site (if any).
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.

For Microsoft SQLXML version shipping with SQL 2000 Gold:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=39547

For Microsoft SQLXML version 2:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=38480

For Microsoft SQLXML version 3:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Rel ease.asp?ReleaseID=38481

This patch can reportedly be installed on systems running SQL Server 2000 SP2. Microsoft indicates that the fix for this issue will be included in SQL Server 2000 SP3.

Microsoft plans to issue Knowledge Base article Q321911 regarding this issue, to be available shortly on Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://search.support.microsoft.com/kb/c.asp?SD=SO&LN=EN-US

Title: Microsoft SQLXML Component of Microsoft SQL Server 2000 Contains a Buffer Overflow That Lets Remote Users Take Full Control of the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Microsoft reported a vulnerability in Microsoft SQLXML, a component of Microsoft SQL Server 2000.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the system to gain full control of the server.
A remote user can send specially crafted data to the system to overflow a buffer and execute arbitrary code on the Microsoft Internet Information Server (IIS) web server.  The vulnerability reportedly exists because the SQLXML ISAPI extension for IIS (which is used with SQL Server 2000) contains an unchecked buffer in the code that processes data queries over HTTP.

A remote user can execute arbitrary code that would allow the remote user to gain complete control over a vulnerable server.  

SQLXML is used to exchange XML data with a SQL Server.  Microsoft's SQLXML HTTP components are set up in a virtual directory on an IIS server (which does not necessarily need to be on the same host as the SQL Server).  According to the report, the system is only vulnerable if the administrator has configured a virtual directory structure for the SQLXML HTTP components on an IIS Server.  The location of the virtual directory on the IIS Server must be known by the remote user.  Also, the IIS Server must have been specifically set up for SQLXML. 

Microsoft advises that if you are running SQL Server 2000 and have enabled the SQLXML HTTP components on an IIS server, you should install the patch.

Microsoft credits Matt Moore of Westpoint Ltd. with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the system running IIS to gain complete control of the computer.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.

For Microsoft SQLXML version shipping with SQL 2000 Gold:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=39547

For Microsoft SQLXML version 2:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=38480

For Microsoft SQLXML version 3:

http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=38481

This patch can reportedly be installed on systems running SQL Server 2000 SP2.  Microsoft indicates that the fix for this issue will be included in SQL Server 2000 SP3.

Microsoft plans to issue Knowledge Base article Q321911 regarding this issue, to be available shortly on Microsoft Online Support web site:

http://search.support.microsoft.com/kb/c.asp?SD=SO&LN=EN-US

Title: Oracle Reports Server Buffer Overflow May Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code, Possibly With SYSTEM Level Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Oracle Reports Server.  A remote user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed on the server in certain situations.
No further details were provided.

Oracle credits David Litchfield of Next Generation Security Software Limited for discovering the bug.

[Editor's note:  NGSSoftware has indicated that they will release additional details about this vulnerability.  When that occurs, we will update this alert accordingly.]
Impact':
A remote user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed on the server.  The code would run with the privileges of the Reports Server.  

According to CERT, the Oracle Reports stand-alone server runs as SYSTEM on Windows NT and Windows 2000 systems.  So, on Windows platforms, this would give the remote user full control over the system.
Solution:
Oracle has released a fixed version (Oracle Reports6i Release 6.0.8.19.0, and Oracle9iAS Reports Release 9.0.2.0.1).  Patches (patch number 2356680) are being made available for Oracle Reports 6i on all supported platforms.  Also, the production release of Oracle9i Reports contains the bug fix for all platforms.

Download currently available patches for your platform from Oracle s Worldwide Support web site, Metalink:

http://metalink.oracle.com

Activate the "Patches" button to get to the patches web page. Enter patch number 2356680 and activate the "Submit" button.

Oracle advises that you check with Metalink or Oracle Worldwide Support Services periodically for patch availability if the patch for your platform is not available.

Title: Oracle Database TNS Listener Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Crash the Server and Possibly Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Oracle Net 9i database server.  A remote user could cause a denial of service condition via the Oracle Net Listener, and may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed.
It is reported that a remote user can send a small amount of specially crafted data to the configured listening endpoint for Oracle Net Listener to cause the Oracle Net Listener to consume available CPU resources on the server.  This would deny service to database users (and to other services on the same server).

Oracle reports that only Microsoft Windows based systems are affected.

Oracle credits David Litchfield of Next Generation Security Software Limited for discovering this bug.

[Editor's note:  NGSSoftware recently issued extremely vague reports that they had notified Oracle of two different bugs in Oracle: a buffer overflow in the Oracle TNS Listener, and a format string bug in the Oracle TNS Listener Control Utility.  It is not clear which bug this Oracle patch addresses, if any.  However Oracle has indicated that the patch is for a buffer overflow and that NGSSoftware discovered the bug.  It is important to note that both of the NGSSoftware reports imply that a remote user can execute arbitrary code on the system with these bugs.

Also note that in March 2002 we issued Alert #1003919 regarding a buffer overflow in the Oracle TNS Listener that could be triggered with a small packet and could cause the server to crash.  This description matches the conditions that Oracle describes in their advisory.  It is not clear if this Oracle patch addresses that vulnerability or not.

If we receive any clarifying information, we will update this alert accordingly.]
Impact':
A remote user can cause the server to consume all available CPU resources, denying resources to database users and other services running on the same host.

It is possible that a remote user can execute arbitrary code on the server, although the vendor's advisory does not confirm that.  If code execution is possible, the code would run with SYSTEM level privileges (which is the default on the affected Windows platforms).
Solution:
Oracle has released a fix (patch number 2367681) for supported releases of Oracle9i, Release 9.0.x on Windows and VM.

Download currently available patches for your platform from Oracle s Worldwide Support web site, Metalink:

http://metalink.oracle.com

Activate the "Patches" button to get to the patches Web page. Enter 2367681 as indicated above and activate the "Submit" button.

Title: IBM Informix SE Database Buffer Overflow in Processing the 'INFORMIXDIR' Environment Variable May Allow Local Users to Obtain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the IBM's Informix Standard Engine (SE).  A local user may be able to obtain root level privileges in certain situations.
It is reported that a local user can trigger a buffer overflow in the processing of the INFORMIXDIR enviroment variable by setting the variable to a value with a size greater than 2023 bytes.

According to the report, the 'sqlexec' program is configured with set user id (suid) root privileges and set group id (sgid) 'informix' group privileges.

A demonstration exploit transcript is provided:

[pask@dimoni lib]$ export INFORMIXDIR=`perl -e 'print "A"x2023'` 
[pask@dimoni lib]$ ./sqlexec
[pask@dimoni lib]$ export INFORMIXDIR=`perl -e 'print "A"x2024'`
[pask@dimoni lib]$ ./sqlexec
Segmentation fault

This overflow allows a local user to overwrite the EIP register and cause arbitrary code to be executed on the system with root level privileges.

The local user must, of course, have execute privileges for the /lib/sqlexec program.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.  [Editor's note:  Although IBM has apparently been notified, it appears that there may be a lack of sufficient internal communications within IBM and the part of IBM responsible for Informix may not have been notified.]
Impact': A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code with root level privileges to gain root access on the system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Microsoft Date Engine (MSDE) Default Configuration Leaves Blank Password for System Administrator Account
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A default configuration vulnerability was reported in Microsoft Data Engine (MSDE).  The component, which is installed as part of various Microsoft and 3rd party applications, is configured with a blank default password for the 'sa' system administrator account.  A remote user can access the system and execute shell commands on the system.
A remote user can access the database port (1433) using the 'sa' account and then can execute shell commands on the system using the 'xp_cmdshell' stored procedure.  The remote user can then upload and execute arbitrary code on the system.  The code would execute using the security context of the MSSQLSERVER service, which is LOCALSYSTEM in a default MSDE installalation.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary shell commands on the system.  The commands may run with Local System privileges (in the default installation).
Solution:
The vendor has described a workaround in the following knowledge base article:

http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;EN-US;q322336

The article describes how to determine if you are affected and, if affected, how to change your 'sa' password or change your authentication mode.

Title: IBM DB2 Database Buffer Overflow in 'db2ckpw' Lets Local Users Gain Root Access on the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in IBM's DB2 database.  A local user can gain root access on the system.
IBM reported that there is a buffer overflow in the 'sqllib/security/db2ckpw' file that is used to verify usernames and passwords. A local user can supply a username that is longer than 8 characters to trigger the overflow and possibly cause arbitrary code to be executed.  Because 'db2ckpw' is configured with set user id (suid) root privileges, the code will run with root level privileges.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code on the system with root privileges to gain root level access on the operating system.
Solution:
The vendor has released FixPaks:

For DB2, version 6, download and apply DB2 v6.1, FixPak 10 (use FixPak 10 version released after 6 March 2002).

For DB2, version 7, download and apply DB2, v7.2, FixPak 6.

These FixPaks can be downloaded from:

DB2 v7:
http://www-4.ibm.com/cgi-bin/db2www/data/db2/udb/winos2unix/support/download.d2w/report#V7

DB2 v6:
http://www-4.ibm.com/cgi-bin/db2www/data/db2/udb/winos2unix/support/download.d2w/report#V6

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: Oracle Database ANSI Outer Join Syntax Lets Valid Users Obtain Unauthorized Access to Sensitive Data in the Data Dictionary
Description:
An access control vulnerability has been reported in the Oracle database.  An authorized and valid user, but with only minimal privileges, can gain unauthorized access to data in the data dictionary.
It is reported that a minimally privileged Oracle user can gain unauthorized access to certain data in the data dictionary by using the ANSI outer join syntax.

A demonstration exploit is provided in which a user with only CREATE SESSION privileges can view sensitive data (in this case, usernames and encrypted passwords):

SQL*Plus: Release 9.0.1.0.1 - Production on Tue Apr 16 15:16:45 2

(c) Copyright 2001 Oracle Corporation.  All rights reserved.


Connected to:
Oracle9i Enterprise Edition Release 9.0.1.1.1 - Production
With the Partitioning option
JServer Release 9.0.1.1.1 - Production

SQL> connect / as sysdba
Connected.
SQL> CREATE USER us1 IDENTIFIED BY us11;

User created.

SQL> Grant Create Session to us1;

Grant succeeded.

SQL> connect us1/us11;
Connected.
SQL> select a.username, a.password
  2  from sys.dba_users a left outer join sys.dba_users b on
  3  b.username = a.username
4	;
5	
USERNAME                       PASSWORD
------------------------------ ------------------------------
SYS                            D4C5016086B2DC6A
SYSTEM                         D4DF7931AB130E37
DBSNMP                         E066D214D5421CCC
[ ]


Another user [Charles J Wertz <wertzcj@buffnet.net>] reports that ANSI syntax is not required for this exploit and that, on Oracle 8 (8.1.6.0.0), user passwords can be viewed as follows:

SQL> set serveroutput on size 1000000
SQL> sta users
SQL> select username, user_id, password from sys.dba_users
   2  /

This will apparently return usernames and encrypted passwords.

Oracle has reportedly assigned bug number 2121935 to the ANSI vulnerability.
Impact': A user with a valid account on the database and with only minimal privileges can gain unauthorized access to sensitive data in the data dictionary, such as usernames and encrypted passwords.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fixed version (Oracle9i, Release 2).  Patches with the base bug fix number, 2121935, are being made available only for supported releases of Oracle9i, Releases 9.0.1.x, database server on all supported platforms.

Download currently available patches for your platform from Oracle's Worldwide Support web site, iSupport, at:

http://isupport.oracle.com

Activate the "Patches" button to get to the patches Web page. Enter the base bug fix number indicated above and activate the "Submit" button.

Oracle notes that none of the Oracle8i (Release 8.1.x), Oracle8 (Release 8.0.x) or Oracle7 database server releases is affected by this vulnerability.

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: A Multitude of Microsoft SQL Server Extended Stored Procedures Have Buffer Overflows That Allow Remote Users to Crash the Database Server or Execute Arbitrary Code on the Server to Gain Full Control of the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Vulnerabilities were reported in a multitude of Microsoft SQL Server extended stored procedures.  Buffer overflows let remote users crash the database server or execute arbitrary code on the server.
It is reported that a remote user can pass long strings of data as parameters to various extended stored procedures to trigger the buffer overflows.

The following extended stored procedures are reported to be vulnerable: 

xp_controlqueueservice
xp_createprivatequeue
xp_createqueue
xp_decodequeuecmd
xp_deleteprivatequeue
xp_deletequeue
xp_displayqueuemesgs
xp_dsninfo
xp_mergelineages
xp_oledbinfo
xp_proxiedmetadata
xp_readpkfromqueue
xp_readpkfromvarbin
xp_repl_encrypt
xp_resetqueue
xp_sqlinventory
xp_unpackcab 

Some of these extended stored procedures are reportedly granted to the public group by default, allowing a non-privileged user to gain full control of the operating system and the database.

A detailed discussion of the vulnerability including results for the specific extended stored procedures listed above are provided in:

http://www.appsecinc.com/resources/alerts/mssql/02-0000.html
Impact': A remote user can cause arbitrary code to be executed by the server with System level privileges, giving the user full control over the database and the operating system.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.

For Microsoft SQL Server 7.0, download the SQL 7.0 Cumulative Security patch at:

http://support.microsoft.com/support/misc/kblookup.asp?id=Q318268

For Microsoft SQL Server 2000, download the SQL Server 2000 Cumulative Security patch at:

http://support.microsoft.com/support/misc/kblookup.asp?id=Q316333

The SQL Server 7.0 patch can reportedly be installed on systems running SQL Server 7.0 SP3.  The SQL Server 2000 patch can reportedly be installed on systems running SQL Server 2000 SP2.

Microsoft reports that the fix for this issue will be included in SQL Server 7.0 SP4  and in SQL Server 2000 SP3.

This patch reportedly supercedes the MS02-007 patch.

Microsoft plans to issue Microsoft Knowledge Base article Q319507 shortly to discuss this patch:

http://search.support.microsoft.com/kb/c.asp?SD=SO&LN=EN-US

Title: Oracle Database ANSI Outer Join Syntax Lets Valid Users Obtain Unauthorized Access to Sensitive Data in the Data Dictionary
Description:
An access control vulnerability has been reported in the Oracle database.  An authorized and valid user, but with only minimal privileges, can gain unauthorized access to data in the data dictionary.
It is reported that a minimally privileged Oracle user can gain unauthorized access to certain data in the data dictionary by using the ANSI outer join syntax.

A demonstration exploit is provided in which a user with only CREATE SESSION privileges can view sensitive data (in this case, usernames and encrypted passwords):

SQL*Plus: Release 9.0.1.0.1 - Production on Tue Apr 16 15:16:45 2

(c) Copyright 2001 Oracle Corporation.  All rights reserved.


Connected to:
Oracle9i Enterprise Edition Release 9.0.1.1.1 - Production
With the Partitioning option

SQL> connect / as sysdba

SQL> CREATE USER us1 IDENTIFIED BY us11;

4	;
5	
USERNAME                       PASSWORD
------------------------------ ------------------------------
SYS                            D4C5016086B2DC6A

DBSNMP                         E066D214D5421CCC
