Another user [Charles J Wertz <wertzcj@buffnet.net>] reports that ANSI syntax is not required for this exploit and that, on Oracle 8 (8.1.6.0.0), user passwords can be viewed as follows:

SQL> set serveroutput on size 1000000
SQL> sta users
SQL> select username, user_id, password from sys.dba_users
   2  /

This will apparently return usernames and encrypted passwords.

Oracle has reportedly assigned bug number 2121935 to the ANSI vulnerability.
Impact': A user with a valid account on the database and with only minimal privileges can gain unauthorized access to sensitive data in the data dictionary, such as usernames and encrypted passwords.
Solution: It is reported that Oracle has fixed this issue in 9.2.  However, no advisories have been posted to Oracle's security web site (http://otn.oracle.com/deploy/security/alerts.htm) as of the date of this entry.

Title: Multiple Vulnerabilities in IBM Informix Web DataBlade Let Remote Users Execute SQL Commands on the Server
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in IBM's Informix Web DataBlade.  A remote user can cause SQL commands to be executed on the database server.
A remote user can reportedly exploit the lack of proper filtering of user-supplied input to inject SQL commands into the SQL server. If access to the web server is controlled, the remote user must have valid and authenticated HTTP access.

Webdriver reportedly fails to properly escape quotes in user-supplied input data. A remote user can use the following URL to obtain access to any page on the web server, regardless of the user's "page level" because the req_level portion of the query is not processed due to the extraneous quote character:

http://victim.com/site/'--/page.html

This will apparently will modify the "path" portion of the query, resulting in the following SQL query being executed:

SELECT webexplode(object,?::html),req_level FROM wbpages WHERE
name='page' AND path='/'--' and req_level <= 100;

A semicolon apparently cannot be inserted, so a remote user must invoke UNION queries in order to execute arbitrary SQL commands.  A full explanation of this method is provided in the Source Message.

The following demonstration exploit transcript shows how to retrieve an HTML formatted list of all database users and passwords:

> telnet victim.com 80
Trying x.x.x.x...
Connected to victim.com.
Escape character is '^]'.
POST /site/ HTTP/1.0
Content-Length: 215
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded

MIval=/'UNION%20SELECT%20webexplode('<html><body><table><?MISQL%20SQL=%22SELECT%20*%20FROM%20wbusers%22><tr>{<td>$*</
[ENTER]

It is reported that a remote user can also exploit a different vulnerability in the system to insert SQL code in web form input so that it will be executed by the system.  This is reportedly possible because Web DataBlade will apparently un-escape the input using the $(WEBUNHTML) function.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': It is reported that a remote user can cause SQL commands to be executed on the server with the privileges of the Webdriver.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Oracle Database TSN Listener Buffer Overflow Lets Local Users Gain Elevated Privileges on the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in an earlier version of the Oracle database.  A local user can execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the Oracle database user.
It is reported that the TNS listener contains a command line buffer overflow.  Because the binary is configured with set user id (suid) oracle privileges, this allows a local user to execute arbitrary code with Oracle user privileges.  

A demonstration exploit is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with oracle user privileges.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Oracle Configurator Filtering Holes Let Remote Users Conduct Cross-Site Scripting Attacks Against Configurator Users to Obtain Sensitive Information
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Oracle has reported a security vulnerability in the Orcale Configurator.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks against Configurator users.
A remote user can reportedly conduct cross-site scripting attacks against Oracle Configurator users that implement the DHMTL UI and Text Features on Internet applications.

It is also reported that a remote user can supply HTML code containing javascript to certain text input boxes of the Configurator so that when other Configurator users view the page, the user-supplied code will be executed in the victim's browser.  The code will reportedly be able to access any information on the page.

According to the report, a remote user can also supply a specially crafted URL with an invalid string for the ?test parameter of the oracle.apps.cz.servlet.UiServlet to cause the servlet to render a page that displays the user-supplied argument.

A remote user can also retrieve version and host information from the oracle.apps.cz.servlet.UiServlet by passing a 'test=version' argument or 'test=host' argument to the servlet.
Impact': A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks to cause arbitrary code to be executed on a Configurator user's browser to obtain sensitive information from Configurator pages.
Solution:
The vendor has released patches to correct the flaws.

Apply the appropriate patch for your version of Oracle Configurator and then add the following line to your jserv.properties file: 

oracle.apps.cz.uiservlet.versionFuncsAvail=false 

These potential vulnerabilities are fixed in CZ patchset H, and in builds 17.32 and 16.53.

Patchset H and later
Patchset G, Build Number 11.5.7.17.32, ARU 2264442, Developer ARU 2257907
Patchset F, Build Number 11.5.6.16.53, ARU 2279864, Developer ARU 2237471

The vendor has provided the following workaround for the Text Features and DHTML UI vulnerability:

"Customers must remove all Text Features from their UIs. If this workaround is not feasible, because the Text Features are required, customers can write validation Functional Companions that examine the user input value for each text feature. Customers can then either reject input with HTML tags, or quote the input text so that the browser will not render the HTML tags when the value is displayed in the browser."

Title: Oracle Database Server TNS Listener Can Be Crashed By Remote Users With a One Byte TCP Packet
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the Oracle database server.  A remote user can cause the Transparent Network Substrate (TNS) listener to crash and no longer accept connections.
It is reported that a remote user can send a single TCP packet (#$00 = 1 byte) to the TNS listener on port 1521 to cause CPU utilization to reach 100%.  No further connections will be accepted, according to the report.  

It is reported that the TNSLISTEN process must be restarted in order for the server to return to normal operations.

The author of the report has provided a Win32 binary (Shadow DoS Analyzer) to test the vulnerability, available at:

http://www.safety-lab.com/SDA.exe

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can cause the TNS listener to crash and stop accepting connections.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Progress Database Buffer Overflow May Let Local Users Gain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Another buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Progress RDBMS.  A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code on the system to gain root privileges.
A buffer overflow vulnerability has been reported in the sqlcpp binary, which is configured with set user id (suid) root privileges. A local user can reportedly trigger the overflow with the following type of command:

/usr/dlc/bin/./sqlcpp `perl -e 'print "A" x 9000'`

It is reported that it may be possible for the local user to cause arbitrary code to be executed via this buffer overflow.
Impact': A local user may be able to execute arbitrary code on the system with root privileges to gain root access on the system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: A Multitude of Microsoft SQL Server Extended Stored Procedures Have Buffer Overflows That Allow Remote Users to Crash the Database Server or Execute Arbitrary Code on the Server to Gain Full Control of the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Vulnerabilities were reported in a multitude of Microsoft SQL Server extended stored procedures.  Buffer overflows let remote users crash the database server or execute arbitrary code on the server.
It is reported that a remote user can pass long strings of data as parameters to various extended stored procedures to trigger the buffer overflows.

The following extended stored procedures are reported to be vulnerable: 

xp_controlqueueservice
xp_createprivatequeue
xp_createqueue
xp_decodequeuecmd
xp_deleteprivatequeue
xp_deletequeue
xp_displayqueuemesgs
xp_dsninfo
xp_mergelineages
xp_oledbinfo
xp_proxiedmetadata
xp_readpkfromqueue
xp_readpkfromvarbin
xp_repl_encrypt
xp_resetqueue
xp_sqlinventory
xp_unpackcab 

Some of these extended stored procedures are reportedly granted to the public group by default, allowing a non-privileged user to gain full control of the operating system and the database.

A detailed discussion of the vulnerability including results for the specific extended stored procedures listed above are provided in:

http://www.appsecinc.com/resources/alerts/mssql/02-0000.html
Impact': A remote user can cause arbitrary code to be executed by the server with System level privileges, giving the user full control over the database and the operating system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the report recommends disabling extended stored procedures and the associated DLLs.

Title: (Oracle Issues Fix) Re: Many Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) Implementations Allow Remote Users to Deny Service or Obtain Access to the System
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Version(s): Enterprise Manager Releases 1.6.5, 2.0, 2.1, 2.2, 9.0.1 running on (or "included with") Oracle 7.3.x, 8.0.x, 8.1.x, 9.0.1.x
Description:
CERT reported that the University of Oulu (Finland) has discovered vulnerabilities in many vendor implementations of the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) version 1.
The Oulu University Secure Programming Group (OUSPG, http://www.ee.oulu.fi/research/ouspg/) reports that there are numerous vulnerabilities in SNMPv1 implementations from many different vendors. A remote user can reportedly cause denial of service attacks or gain elevated privileges on the system. The extent of the vulnerabilities depends on the specific vendor implementation. 

Oracle reports that the Enterprise Manager (EM) SNMP monitoring capability for Oracle Database is affected, potentially allowing a remote user to conduct a denial of service attack against EM's "master_peer" agent.  The system is only vulnerable when the SNMP monitoring feature is used in addition to the default functionality provided by EM. 

According to the report, the "master_peer" agent of EM, which provides the SNMP monitoring capability, is vulnerable to ill-formed SNMP requests that render the master_peer agent unable to respond to subsequent SNMP requests or to send SNMP messages.

Oracle notes that the "Intelligent Agent" is not affected.
Impact': A remote user may be able to cause denial of service conditions.
Solution:
Oracle has issued a fix (patch/bug fix number 2224724), available on Metalink at:

http://metalink.oracle.com

Activate the "Patches" button to get to the patches Web page. Enter the patch/bug fix number indicated above and activate the "Submit" button.

Title: Microsoft SQL Server 'xp_dirtree' Buffer Overflow Lets Users Crash the Database Service
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in Microsoft SQL Server.  A user can cause the server to crash.
It is reported that the extended stored procedure xp_dirtree, which allows users to retrieve the subdirectory structure of a specified drive or folder, contains a buffer overflow.  A remote user can supply a long string to trigger the overflow.  It is reported that a remote user can pass a parameter (N) as unicode to crash the server, as shown:

xp_dirtree N'XXXXXX...'----> many, many X's
Impact': A user can cause the database server to crash.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report suggests as a workaround to drop the extended store procedure and its DLL.

Title: Microsoft XML Core Services in SQL Server 2000 Lets Remote Scripts Access and Send Local Files
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Microsoft issued Security Bulletin MS02-008 confirming a previously reported vulnerability in the Microsoft XML Core Services that affects Microsoft SQL Server 2000.  A remote user may be able to access files and content on another user's computer.
Microsoft XML Core Services (MSXML) includes the XMLHTTP ActiveX control. A flaw reportedly exists in how the XMLHTTP control applies IE security zone settings to a redirected data stream returned in response to a request for data from a web site. A remote user could specify a data source that is on the user s local system and then use this to return information from the local system to the attacker's web site. 

Microsoft reports that affected versions of MSXML ship as part of several products. The patch mentioned in their advisory should reportedly be applied if any of the following Microsoft products are being used: 

  Microsoft Windows XP 
  Microsoft Internet Explorer 6.0 
  Microsoft SQL Server 2000 

MSXML can apparentely be installed separately as a DLL in the system32 subdirectory. Users that have any of the following files in that directory should install the patch:

  MSXML2.DLL 
  MSXML3.DLL 
  MSXML4.DLL 

The vendor notes that MSXML.DLL is not affected (as it is an earlier version).

Microsoft has assigned this vulnerability a "Moderate" risk rating for Internet and Intranet Servers and a "Critical" risk rating for Client Systems. 

This affects Microsoft XML Core Services 2.6, 3.0, and 4.0, which also includes Microsoft Windows XP, SQL Server 2000, and Internet Explorer 6.0. 

[Editor's note:  This flaw was reported on our site in December 2001 as a bug in the Microsoft XMLHTTP component shipped with Internet Explorer 6.  However, Microsoft has confirmed that the bug also affects products other than IE.]
Impact': A remote user can create a script in an HTML web page or e-mail message that, when loaded and executed by the target (victim) user's browser, will access and send known files on the target user's computer.  The script may also be able to access web site content from a web site that the target user has recently visited, including content that the target user submitted to the web site.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix for Microsoft XML Core Services (installed as part of SQL Server 2000):

  http://www.microsoft.com/Windowsupdate 

This can be installed on MSXML versions 2.6 Gold, 3.0 Gold, 3.0 Service Pack 1, 3.0 Service Pack 2, or 4.0 Gold

This fix will reportedly be included in the following future service packs:

  MSXML, 3.0 SP3 and 4.0 Service Pack 1 
  Microsoft Windows 2000 Service Pack 3 
  Microsoft Windows XP Service Pack 1 
  Microsoft Internet Explorer 6.0 Service Pack 1 
  Microsoft SQL Server 2000 Service Pack 3 

Microsoft plans to release Knowledge Base article Q317244 regarding this flaw.

Title: (Microsoft Issues Fix) Microsoft SQL Server Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Crash the Server and May Allow Remote Code to Be Executed on the Database Server
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in Microsoft SQL Server.  A remote user may be able to execute arbitrary code on the database server and can cause the database server to crash.
Microsoft has confirmed that unchecked buffer exists in the handling of OLE DB provider names in "ad hoc" connections.  For details on potential exploit methods, see the original alert (in the Message History).

A remote user could trigger the buffer overrun and either cause the SQL Server service to fail, or to cause code to run in the security context of the SQL Server. Microsoft reports that SQL Server can be configured to run in various security contexts, and by default runs as a domain user.
Impact': A remote user can cause the database server to crash.  A remote user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed by the database server.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.

The SQL Server 7.0 Cumulative Security patch is available at:

http://support.microsoft.com/support/misc/kblookup.asp?id=Q318268 

The SQL Server 2000 Cumulative Security patch is available at:

http://support.microsoft.com/support/misc/kblookup.asp?id=Q316333 

The SQL Server 7.0 patch can be installed on systems running SQL Server 7.0 SP3.  The SQL Server 2000 patch can be installed on systems running SQL Server 2000 SP2. 


Microsoft reportedly plans to include these fixes in SQL Server 7.0 SP4 and SQL Server 2000 SP3. 

This patch reportedly supercedes MS01-060.

Microsoft plans to release Knowledge Base article Q317979 to discusses this.

Microsoft has assigned this vulnerability a "Moderate" risk level for Internet Servers, Intranet Servers, and Client Systems.

Title: Microsoft SQL Server Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Crash the Server and May Allow Remote Code to Be Executed on the Database Server
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in Microsoft SQL Server.  A remote user may be able to execute arbitrary code on the database server and can cause the database server to crash.
It is reported that the OpenDataSource and OpenRowset functions, which are accessible to all users, contain an unchecked buffer in the processing of the "provider name" parameter.

In SQL Server 7, the overflow reportedly starts at character number 6819.  The database server can apparently be crashed if the amount of characters is >= 6918, as shown below:

SELECT *
FROM OpenDataSource(
'XXXXXXXXXXX...' ---> 6819 characteres or more
,'')...nothing

SELECT * FROM OPENROWSET(
'XXXXXXXXXXX...' ---> 6819 characteres or more
,'',
'')

In SQL Server 2000, the overflow reportedly starts at character number 6887.  If the number of characteres is >= 6998, the server will reportedly crash, as shown below:

SELECT *
FROM OpenDataSource(
'XXXXXXXXXXX...' ---> 6887 characteres or more
,'')...nothing

SELECT * FROM OPENROWSET(
'XXXXXXXXXXX...' ---> 6887 characteres or more
,'',
'')

A remote user can send a certain number of characters to overwrite critical program registers, according to the report.  This may result in arbitrary code being executed on the database server.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can cause the database server to crash.  A remote user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed by the database server.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Vendor Responds and Issues Fix) Re: Thunderstone Software's texis(CGI) for the TEXIS Database Discloses Path Information to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the texis(CGI) component of the TEXIS relational database management system.  A remote user can view installation path information.
A remote user can craft a query that includes an invalid path to cause the script to reveal the full path to the web server's web root directory. In some cases, cgi version and operating system information is also disclosed.

The vendor has reportedly responded that this is a feature and not a bug.  Even so, they have offerred a fix (see the Solution section).
Impact': A remote user can view the web root directory path.
Solution:
The vendor notes that this is a feature, not a bug.  However, the vendor reports that customers can use vhttpd and use an EntryScript to check for the existence of a script prior to invoking texis, taking appropriate action if the script does not exist (to avoid having the path information disclosed).

The vendor has also reportedly initiated a modification to resolve the issue.  Customers that are interested in this modification are advised to contact Thunderstone tech support.

Title: (Vendor Issues Workaround Instructions) Re: Oracle Database Server PL/SQL Design Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Library Functions to Obtain SYSTEM Level Access to the Server
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
NGSSoftware reported a vulnerability in Oracle.  A remote user can execute arbitrary library functions on the server to gain user level or SYSTEM level access to the server, depending on the underlying operating system.
Oracle Procedural Language/Structured Query Language (PL/SQL) can be extended to call functions exported by operating system libraries or Dynamic Link Libraries.  Ordinarily, a user must have the CREATE LIBRARY permission to create such a function.  However, it is reported that the Oracle database server can be made to load arbitrary libraries and execute arbitrary functions by a remote, unauthenticated user.

It is reported that when a PL/SQL package is required to run an external procedure, the database process connects to the Listener and requests that the Listener load the relevant library and call the function with any relevant parameters.  The Listener, in turn, launches another process and directs the database to connect to that newly launched process.  The database apparently connects to this new process via named pipes without authenticating to the process.

As a result, a remote user can reportedly masquerade as a valid database process and then execute any function on the system.  It is also reported that this communications can be forced to occur via network sockets instead of named pipes, which allows this exploit to occur remotely.

The arbitrary function would be executed with the privileges of the database process.  On UNIX/Linux-based systems, the Oracle database process typically runs with "oracle" user privileges.  On Windows-based systems, the process typically runs with SYSTEM level privileges.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary system functions on the server with the privileges of the database server.
Solution:
The vendor has provided detailed workaround directions.  See the Source Message or the vendor's advisory, available at:

http://otn.oracle.com/deploy/security/pdf/plsextproc_alert.pdf

Title: Oracle Application Server PL/SQL Module for Apache Has Buffer Overflows That Allow Remote Users to Execute Arbitrary Code and Gain Access to the Server
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
NGSSoftware reported a buffer overflow vulnerability in the Oracle Application Server PL/SQL module for Apache.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the server and gain user level or SYSTEM level access on the server.
It is reported that a remote user can send a long request to the plsql module to cause the module to crash or to cause arbitrary code to be executed on the server.  The following type of long requests reportedly will trigger the vulnerability:

- A long password set in the Authorization HTTP client header
- A long cache directory name in the cache form
- A long password in the adddad form

It is reported that some attacks require the remote user to know the adminPath name.

The code will be executed with the privileges of the web server.  On Windows NT/2000 systems, it is reported that the Oracle Apache web server by default runs with local SYSTEM privileges, allowing the remote user to gain full control of the system.

A denial of service attack is also possible, according to the report.  A remote user can make a request to the pls module with an HTTP client Authorization header set but with no auth type specified to cause an access violation on the server.  A restart is required to return the server to normal operation.
Impact': A remote user can cause the server to crash.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the server with the privileges of the web server, which may be user-level or SYSTEM-level privileges.
Solution:
It is reported that Oracle has released a patch, available at:

http://metalink.oracle.com
Underlying OS Comments: Tested on Sun SPARC Solaris 2.6, MS Windows NT/2000 Server, HP-UX 11.0/32-bit

Title: Oracle Database Server PL/SQL Design Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Library Functions to Obtain SYSTEM Level Access to the Server
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
NGSSoftware reported a vulnerability in Oracle.  A remote user can execute arbitrary library functions on the server to gain user level or SYSTEM level access to the server, depending on the underlying operating system.
Oracle Procedural Language/Structured Query Language (PL/SQL) can be extended to call functions exported by operating system libraries or Dynamic Link Libraries.  Ordinarily, a user must have the CREATE LIBRARY permission to create such a function.  However, it is reported that the Oracle database server can be made to load arbitrary libraries and execute arbitrary functions by a remote, unauthenticated user.

It is reported that when a PL/SQL package is required to run an external procedure, the database process connects to the Listener and requests that the Listener load the relevant library and call the function with any relevant parameters.  The Listener, in turn, launches another process and directs the database to connect to that newly launched process.  The database apparently connects to this new process via named pipes without authenticating to the process.

As a result, a remote user can reportedly masquerade as a valid database process and then execute any function on the system.  It is also reported that this communications can be forced to occur via network sockets instead of named pipes, which allows this exploit to occur remotely.

The arbitrary function would be executed with the privileges of the database process.  On UNIX/Linux-based systems, the Oracle database process typically runs with "oracle" user privileges.  On Windows-based systems, the process typically runs with SYSTEM level privileges.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary system functions on the server with the privileges of the database server.
Solution:
The vendor is reportedly working on a patch.

NGSSoftware has provided some interim recommendations to mitigate risk:

"The first line of defense is, of course, with the use of a firewall. No one should be able to access the listener port of 1521 from the Internet. This not only helps mitigate the risk concerned with this problem but a slew of others, too.

Moving to the Oracle database server itself, PLSExtproc functionality can be removed if not needed. To do this remove the relevant entries in tnsnames.ora and listener.ora. The PLS External Procedure service can have many different names depending upon the system and Oracle version installed.  This could be icache_extproc, PLSExtproc or extproc. It is also suggested that extproc(.exe) be deleted, too, on the off chance that an attacker, replaces the entries in tnsnames.ora and listener.ora.

If this functionality is required then it is possible to limit the machines that may access the listener. Whilst this is a trust mechanism based only on IP address it does help. The process is called "valid node checking" and requires a modification to the sqlnet.ora file found in the $ORACLE_HOME\network\admin directory. Add the entries

 tcp.validnode_checking = YES
 tcp.invited_nodes = (10.1.1.2, scylla)

Replace 10.1.1.2 or Scylla in this example with the hosts that require access. Any host not listed here will still be able to make a TCP connection to the listener but the listener will simply terminate the connection.  Invited nodes should be restricted to machines that require access.

As another step towards help mitigating the risk, you could set the listener listening on a non-default port (i.e. not 1521). Whilst this is not a great solution, as anyone with a TCP port scanner has a highly likely chance of finding the listener, it still helps.

Finally, on Windows NT/2000 the Oracle processes should not be running as local SYSTEM. It is suggested that a low privileged account be created and the Oracle processes run as this user. This account will need to be given the "Logon as a service" account privilege."

Title: Thunderstone Software's texis(CGI) for the TEXIS Database Discloses Path Information to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the texis(CGI) component of the TEXIS relational database management system.  A remote user can view installation path information.
A remote user can craft a query that includes an invalid path to cause the script to reveal the full path to the web server's web root directory.  In some cases, cgi version and operating system information is also disclosed.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can view the web root directory path.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Conectiva Linux MySQL Distribution May Allow Local Users to Obtain Sensitive Information
Description:
Conectiva reported a vulnerability in their distribution of MySQL.  A local user could view potentially sensitive information in the log files.
It is reported that the package shipped with Conectiva Linux 6.0 and prior versions uses the /var/log/mysql file to log all queries (by default), including queries to change passwords via SQL commands.  The Conectiva package apparently sets the permissions of this file to world-readable permissions (0644).  A local user could view sensitive information in the log files.
Impact': A local user could view potentially sensitive information in the log files.
Solution:
Conectiva has issued a fix and recommends that all MySQL users upgrade their packages.  If an upgrade cannot be made at this time, Conectiva provides the following workaround:

Change the permissions of the log file manually:

 chmod 600 /var/log/mysql*
 chown mysql.mysql /var/log/mysql*

Conectiva has issued the following fixed packages:

ftp://atualizacoes.conectiva.com.br/5.0/SRPMS/MySQL-3.23.36-14U50_1cl.src.rpm
ftp://atualizacoes.conectiva.com.br/5.0/i386/MySQL-3.23.36-14U50_1cl.i386.rpm
ftp://atualizacoes.conectiva.com.br/5.1/SRPMS/MySQL-3.23.36-14U51_1cl.src.rpm
ftp://atualizacoes.conectiva.com.br/5.1/i386/MySQL-3.23.36-14U51_1cl.i386.rpm
ftp://atualizacoes.conectiva.com.br/6.0/SRPMS/MySQL-3.23.36-14U60_1cl.src.rpm
ftp://atualizacoes.conectiva.com.br/6.0/RPMS/MySQL-3.23.36-14U60_1cl.i386.rpm

Users of Conectiva Linux version 6.0 or higher may use apt to perform upgrades of RPM packages:
 - add the following line to /etc/apt/sources.list if it is not there yet
   (you may also use linuxconf to do this):

 rpm [cncbr] ftp://atualizacoes.conectiva.com.br 6.0/conectiva updates

(replace 6.0 with the correct version number if you are not running CL6.0)

 - run:                 apt-get update
 - after that, execute: apt-get upgrade

Detailed instructions reagarding the use of apt and upgrade examples can be found at http://distro.conectiva.com.br/atualizacoes/#apt?idioma=en

Title: SQLData Enterprise Server Stack Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code with SYSTEM Privileges
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the SQLData Enterprise Server from SQLData Systems, Inc.  A remote user can cause the application to crash and may be able to execute arbitrary code with SYSTEM privileges and take full control of the server.
SecurityFocus reported that a remote user can create a specially crafted request with a long string of characters to trigger a stack overflow.  [Editor's note:  This is believed to be an HTTP GET request, but the report did not indicate the type of request.]

According to the report, this allows the remote user to execute arbitrary code with SYSTEM privileges on the server or cause the application to crash.

This bug was reportedly discovered by Mr. Giggles <giggles@pullonthis.com>.
Impact': A remote user can cause the application to crash or can execute arbitrary code with SYSTEM level privileges.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: mSQL Database Can Be Crashed By Local Users
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability has been reported in the Mini SQL (mSQL) database server.  A local user can cause the database to crash.
It is reported that a local user can cause the database to crash by creating a table with a large column.

A demonstration exploit transcript is provided:

mSQL > create table qqq (www char(1000000)) \g

Query OK.  1 row(s) modified or retrieved.

mSQL > select * from qqq \g

ERROR : MSQL server has gone away

[Editor's Note:  It is not clear whether one local user can crash the database for sessions belonging to other local users or not.]
Impact': A local user with privileges to modify the database can cause the database to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Microsoft SQL Server Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code in the Security Context of the SQL Server
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
@Stake reported several buffer overflows in SQL Server.  A remote user can cause denial of service to the SQL Server service or can execute arbitrary code in the security context of the SQL Server.
Some SQL Server functions that enable database queries to generate text messages reportedly contain a buffer overflow.  Several of the functions apparently do not verify that the requested text will fit into the allocated buffer.  As a result, a remote user could cause the SQL Server service to fail or could execute arbitrary code in the security context of the SQL Server service.  

@Stake reports that a remote user must have permission to execute SQL queries either directly or by leveraging SQL Command Injection flaws in order to exploit these vulnerabilities.

The vulnerable functions are reported to be:

- raiserror() function (accessible to all users)
- formatmessage() built in function (accessible to all users)
- xp_sprintf extended stored procedure (accessible to the 'public' role by default)
Impact': A remote user could cause arbitrary code to be executed in the security context of the SQL Server service or could cause denial of service conditions for the service.  It is reported that SQL Server typically runs with Administrator privileges, but that depends on the installation.
Solution:
Microsoft has issued a fix, available at the following locations:

SQL Server 7.0:
http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=35066 

SQL Server 2000:
http://www.microsoft.com/Downloads/Release.asp?ReleaseID=35067 

The vendor reports that the SQL Server 7.0 patch can be installed on systems running SQL Server 7.0 Service Pack 3.  The SQL Server 2000 patch can be installed on systems running SQL Server 2000 Service Pack 1. 

Microsoft indicates that the fix for this issue will be included in SQL Server 2000 Service Pack 2.

See the Vendor URL for instructions on how to verify the patch installation.

Title: (Oracle Issues Fix) Re: Oracle Database dbsnmp Component Lets Local Users Obtain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in Oracle's dbsnmp module that allows local users to obtain root level privileges.
The dbsnmp module is configured with set user id (suid) root privileges and allows local users to obtain root privileges.  When a local user executes dbsnmp, the module makes a call to chown and chgrp but does not specify the path for these calls.  As a result, a local user can define the PATH variable so that an alternate program is executed with root privileges.

The vendor has reportedly been contacted.

A demonstration exploit transcript is included in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root level privileges, giving the user root level access.
Solution:
Oracle strongly recommended that affected users upgrade to Oracle8I database server Release 8.1.6, or higher.  Alternatively, issue the following command in $ORACLE_HOME/bin

% chmod o-rx dbsnmp

Title: (Oracle Issues Fix) Re: Oracle Database Component (dbsnmp) Lets Local Users with Oracle Group Privileges Obtain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability in Oracle Database dbsnmp for Linux (and possibly other platforms) lets any local user with Oracle group privileges obtain root level privileges on the host.
A buffer overflow reportedly exists in the ORACLE_HOME enviroment variable and can be triggered by a value that is longer than 749 bytes.  Because dbsnmp is configured with set user id (suid) root privileges, the overflow can be used to execute arbitrary code with root level privileges.

A demonstration overflow transcript is provided in the Source Message.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A local user with Oracle group privileges (gid oracle) can execute arbitrary code on the system that will run with root level privileges, giving the local user root privileges (euid 0).
Solution:
Oracle has fixed this potential security vulnerability in the Oracle9i database server and has backported the fix to supported Oracle8i database server Releases 8.0.6, 8.1.6, 8.1.7 and 9.0.1. See the dbsnmp_patch_matrix,on OTN for patch/platform information. (The base bug filed for this bug was 1918073).

Download the patch for your platform from Oracle' s Worldwide Support web site, Metalink, http://metalink.oracle.com. Please check Metalink periodically for the patch availability if the patch for your platform is not yet available.

Title: Oracle9iAS Web Cache Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Sending Malformed HTTP Content Length Header
Description:
SecurityFocus reported a denial of service vulnerability in Oracle9iAS Web Cache.  A remote user can cause the service to crash.
It is reported that a remote user can send an HTTP request with a header that has Content Length of 0, followed by three "0a" strings, to cause the web cache process to crash.

A manual restart of the service is apparently required to resume normal functionality. 

SecurityFocus notes that this vulnerability was discovered by Magnus Mickelsson.
Impact': A remote user can cause the web cache service to crash, requiring a manual restart to return to normal operations.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Informix Database May Disclose Files on the System to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in several sites running Informix.  A remote user can obtain any file on the system.
A remote user can reportedly view any file on the system by using the '/../' string in the URL request.  The sites where this flaw was discovered were apparently using Informix with the Netscape-Enterprise/4.0 server on the Solaris UNIX operating system.

On the affected sites, the image files are linked as such:

http://[targethost]/ifx/?
LO=00000001a6b7c8d900000003000000030004334d
38e02543000000000001eb800000000000000000000
0000000000000000000000000000000000000000000
000000000000000000 

This apparently causes the Web DataBlade Module to retrieve an image from the wbBinaries system table.

A remote user can obtain the contents of a directory (for example, the /etc directory) by using the following type of URL:

http://[targethost]/ifx/?LO=../../../etc/

Files can also be retrieved via this method.
Impact': A remote user can retrieve files from the system that are readable by the Web DataBlade Module.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Microsoft SQL Server May Disclose Database Passwords When Creating Data Transformation Service (DTS) Packages
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Microsoft's SQL Server software.  When Data Transformation Service (DTS) packages are created, database passwords may be disclosed within the package.
It is reported that the saved file does not encrypt the passwords that the package will use when executed.  As a result, the password of the user creating the package may be disclosed to the recipient of the DTS package.
Impact': A user receiving a DTS package may obtain the SQL Server database password of the user that created the package.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the report suggests that using a sensitive user account to create DTS packages would not be advised.

Title: Progress Database Format String Vulnerability Yields Root Privileges to Local Users
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A format string vulnerability has been reported in Progress Database.  A local user can execute arbitrary shell commands with root level privileges.
The vulnerability is reportedly in the processing of the PROMSGS environment variable.  A local user can set this variable to a specially crafted format string to potentially cause arbitrary shell commands to be executed with root level privileges.

It is reported that all set user id (suid) programs in the dlc/bin dir are vulnerable, including _dbutil, _mprosrv, _mprshut, _proapsv, _progres, _proutil, _rfutil, _probuild, and prolib.
Impact': A local user may be able to execute arbitrary shell commands with root level privileges, giving the user root level access on the host.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Oracle Label Security Access Control Flaw Lets Users Gain Unauthorized Access to Data in the Database
Description:
Oracle reported a flaw in Oracle Label Security that allows users to gain unauthorized access to data at a higher level than they are authorized.
It is reported that three separate vulnerabilities exist and that they can be triggered when the Oracle Label Security audit functionality, SET_LABEL, or SQL*Predicate functionality is used.

Oracle Label Security 8.1.7 ships in the Oracle Enterprise Edition 8.1.7 CDpack.
Impact': A user can obtain unauthorized access to data at a higher level than the user is authorized for.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a patch.

Patch for Oracle Label Security 8.1.7:

The Oracle Label Security 8.1.7 security bug numbers 1816589, 1815273, and 2029809 are fixed in patch number 2022108. Additional Oracle Label Security bugs, not related to security, are also fixed in the patch.  The patch is available at:

http://metalink.oracle.com

Patch for Oracle Label Security 9.0.1:

The Oracle9i database server patch set 2 will include patches for all known Oracle Label Security bugs, including the bugs identified in Oracle Label Security 8.1.7. Availability of the Oracle9i database server patch set 2 is pending.

Title: (Oracle Issues Workaround) Re: Oracle Database Permission Configuration Error Lets Local Users Modify Database Files, Configuration Files, and Executables
Description:
PlazaSite reported a vulnerability in Oracle 8.0.5 that allows any local user to modify any file owned by the 'oracle' user.
It is reported that there is a write permision checking error in an unspecified component of Oracle that allows any local user to write to any file owned by the 'oracle' user.
Impact': A local user can modify and corrupt the database and modify the oracle binaries.
Solution:
The vendor plans to issue a fix in the next release of the Oracle database server which is Oracle9i, Release 2, only.  All other releases of the Oracle database (8.0.x, 8.1.x and 9.0.1) must use the following workaround:

Change the file permissions on the oracle executable as follows:
% chmod o-x oracle

The vendor has provided the following notes regarding the workaround:

"The workaround suggested above will permit only the owner of the oracle executable and users defined in the OS DBA group to run the oracle executable directly. With the execute permissions for  others  removed, other users cannot connect to an Oracle database server using the BEQ driver. If the BEQ driver is being used to connect to an Oracle database, a client program (such as SQLPLUS) will fork its processes and try to execute the oracle executable directly. This operation will fail because such a client program will run with the OS user s privileges who no longer has execute permission on the oracle executable. To avoid this problem, local users must connect to an Oracle database using the IPC driver which makes it possible to connect to a TNS listener listening on an Oracle database. The TNS listener will need to be started by a user that has execute permissions on the oracle executable."

Title: (Oracle Describes a Workaround) Re: Oracle Database otrcrep Component Buffer Overflow Lets Local Users Obtain Escalated Group and User Privileges
Version(s): All Oracle database server releases (8.0.x, 8.1.x and 9.0.1)
Description:
PlazaSite reported another vulnerability in an Oracle database component.  This vulnerability resides in otrcrep and allows any local user to obtain oracle user privileges and privileges of the database administrator group.
There is reportedly a buffer overflow in otrcrep binary that can be used by any local user to obtain user privileges of the oracle user and group privileges of the dba group (euid=oracle and egid=dba).

Demonstration exploit code is included in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can obtain oracle user privileges and database administrator group privileges, allowing the local user to access the database.
Solution:
Oracle plans to correct the issue in the next release of Oracle 9i (Release 2).  All other releases of the Oracle database (8.0.x, 8.1.x and 9.0.1) must use the following workaround, provided by Oracle.

As a workaround, disable Oracle Trace by setting its control parameter in init<SID>.ora as follows:

  oracle_trace_enable=FALSE

Also change the file permissions on all of the Oracle Trace executables as follows:

% chmod -s otrccol otrccref otrcfmt otrcrep
% chmod 751 otrccol otrccref otrcfmt otrcrep

Title: Progress Database PROTERMCAP and PROMSGS Errors Let Local Users Execute Arbitrary Code with Root Level Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Progress Database in its handling of the PROTERMCAP and PROMSGS files.  A local user could trigger a buffer overflow in a set user id (suid) root process and gain root level access on the host.
It is reported that a malformed PROTERMCAPS or PROMSGS file can cause a memory overwrite to occur.  A local user can apparently put a several few thousand characters on each line of the file to cause it to crash various set user id (suid) root executables.

An example malformed line and a demonstration exploit transcript is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root level privileges.
Solution: The vendor has reportedly released patches, but no information was provided on the patches.  Contact the vendor for more information.

Title: Progress RDBMS Database System Has Multiple Vulnerabilities That Permit Local Users to Gain Root Level Access on the Host
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
Several vulnerabilities have been reported in the Progress RDBMS database system.  Numerous buffer overflows exist as well as some format string vulnerabilities.  Local users can gain root privileges.
It is reported that buffer overflow vulnerabilities exist in many components of the software.  Some of those components are listed in the Source Message.  A local user can call these programs with lengthy command line parameters to trigger the buffer overflow and cause arbitrary code to be execute with the privileges of the program.

Format string vulnerabilities also reportedly exist.  For example, the root-initiated jvmStart module, which starts the Java Virtual Machine, contains an input validation flaw that allows a local user to cause arbitrary code to be executed on the host.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A local user can cause arbitrary code to be executed with root level privileges, giving the local user root level privileges on the host.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: WinMySQLadmin Database Administration Tool Discloses MySQL Password to Local Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in WinMySQLadmin, a Windows-based administration tool for the MySQL database.  A local user can obtain the MySQL password.
It is reported that WinMySQLadmin stores the MySQL password in clear text in the file c:\winnt\my.ini, shown below:

---<my.ini>---
#This File was made using the WinMySQLadmin 1.1 Tool

[mysqld]
basedir=C:/mysql
datadir=C:/mysql/data

[WinMySQLadmin]
Server=C:/mysql/bin/mysqld-nt.exe
user=admin
password=XXXXX (in clear text)
QueryInterval=30
---<my.ini>---
Impact': A local user can obtain the MySQL password.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Informix-SQL Database Application Lets Local Users Write to Files on the System with Root Level Privileges
Description:
Hackerslab reported a vulnerability in Informix-SQL that allows a local user to create or overwrite files on the host with root level privileges, potentially giving the user root level access on the host.
The application includes some set user id (suid) root applications that allow a local user to create any file with root privilege. These suid files include onbar_d, ondblog, onsmsync, and onsrvapd, all in the informix/bin Informix HOME directory.  They create temporary files with predictable file names, allowing a local user to create a symlink from the predictable file name to another file on the system.  When the utilities are executed, they will write to the symlinked file with root level privileges.

A demonstration exploit transcript is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can create any file with root level privileges, giving the local user root level access on the host.
Solution:
No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report provides a workaround, involving removing suid permission from certain Informix files:

$ su -
# cd ~informix/bin  (Informix HOME Directory)
# chmod o-s onbar_d  ondblog  onsmsync  onsrvapd

Title: Oracle Database Permission Configuration Error Lets Local Users Modify Database Files, Configuration Files, and Executables
Description:
PlazaSite reported a vulnerability in Oracle 8.0.5 that allows any local user to modify any file owned by the 'oracle' user.
It is reported that there is a write permision checking error in an unspecified component of Oracle that allows any local user to write to any file owned by the 'oracle' user.
Impact': A local user can modify and corrupt the database and modify the oracle binaries.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Oracle Database otrcrep Component Buffer Overflow Lets Local Users Obtain Escalated Group and User Privileges
Description:
PlazaSite reported another vulnerability in an Oracle database component.  This vulnerability resides in otrcrep and allows any local user to obtain oracle user privileges and privileges of the database administrator group.
There is reportedly a buffer overflow in otrcrep binary that can be used by any local user to obtain user privileges of the oracle user and group privileges of the dba group (euid=oracle and egid=dba).

Demonstration exploit code is included in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can obtain oracle user privileges and database administrator group privileges, allowing the local user to access the database.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Oracle Database Component (dbsnmp) Lets Local Users with Oracle Group Privileges Obtain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability in Oracle Database dbsnmp for Linux (and possibly other platforms) lets any local user with Oracle group privileges obtain root level privileges on the host.
A buffer overflow reportedly exists in the ORACLE_HOME enviroment variable and can be triggered by a value that is longer than 749 bytes.  Because dbsnmp is configured with set user id (suid) root privileges, the overflow can be used to execute arbitrary code with root level privileges.

A demonstration overflow transcript is provided in the Source Message.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A local user with Oracle group privileges (gid oracle) can execute arbitrary code on the system that will run with root level privileges, giving the local user root privileges (euid 0).
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (A User Provides Additional Information) Re: Oracle Database dbsnmp Component Lets Local Users Obtain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): Oracle 8.1.5; Oracle 8.1.6 is reported to be not vulnerable
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in Oracle's dbsnmp module that allows local users to obtain root level privileges.
A user notes that this vulnerability likely existed with 8.0.5 and possibly prior versions.  The user also indicates that, as tested on SPARC/solaris 2.7, oracle-8.1.6 and oracle-8.1.7 are vulnerable.

The user also reports that false $ORACLE_HOME values can be used to exploit the module.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root level privileges, giving the user root level access.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Oracle Database dbsnmp Component Lets Local Users Obtain Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Version(s): Oracle 8.1.5; Oracle 8.1.6 is reported to be not vulnerable
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in Oracle's dbsnmp module that allows local users to obtain root level privileges.
The dbsnmp module is configured with set user id (suid) root privileges and allows local users to obtain root privileges.  When a local user executes dbsnmp, the module makes a call to chown and chgrp but does not specify the path for these calls.  As a result, a local user can define the PATH variable so that an alternate program is executed with root privileges.

The vendor has reportedly been contacted.

A demonstration exploit transcript is included in the Source Message.
Impact': A local user can execute arbitrary code with root level privileges, giving the user root level access.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Critical Path's InJoin LDAP Directory Server Can Be Crashed By Remote Users and May Allow Remote Users to Execute Arbitrary Code and Gain Elevated Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
It is reported that Critical Path's InJoin LDAP directory servers can be crashed by remote users and may allow remote users to execute arbitrary code to gain elevated privileges on the server.
No additional details are available.

This vulnerability is the same LDAP vulnerability described in CERT Advisory CA-2001-18 ("Multiple Vulnerabilities in Several Implementations of the Lightweight Directory Access Protocol"), dated July 16, 2001.  The Critical Path InJoin server was not included in the CERT advisory.
Impact': A remote user can cause the LDAP server to crash and may allow remote users to execute arbitrary code to gain elevated privileges on the server.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Microsoft SQL Database Server RPC Input Validation Failure Lets Remote Users Crash the Database Service
Version(s): Microsoft SQL Server 7.0, Microsoft SQL Server 2000
Description:
Microsoft reported that Bindview discovered a vulnerability in the RPC servers associated with several products, including Microsoft SQL Server database. The security hole allows a remote user to send a malformed RPC message to the SQL Server potentially causing the database services to crash or causing the operating system to become unstable. 
It is reported that one or more RPC servers used by SQL Server fails to validate input received from an RPC stub (which is based on user-supplied data). If the data does not match the specifications in the stub's interface definition or if the data is otherwise out of range, the RPC server may behave unpredicatbly or may crash.

Similar flaws are contained in Microsoft Exchange Server and Microsoft's Windows 2000 and Windows NT operating systems (see the separate Alerts for these other product vulnerabilities).
Impact': A remote user can send a malformed RPC message to Microsoft SQL Server to cause it to crash or cause the operating system to become unstable.
Solution: The vendor has released patches. See the Vendor URL to obtain the latest patch information.

Title: Oracle 8i Enterprise Edition Server Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code and Obtain Privileges on the Server, Possibly Including Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
CERT reported a vulnerability with Oracle 8i Enterprise Edition server that allows a remote user to execute arbitrary code and obtain elevated privileges (typically root level privileges) on the server.
The vulnerabilities reportedly reside in the code used to process LDAP requests.

A remote user can create a specially crafted packet that features invalid encodings of BER OBJECT-IDENTIFIER values to trigger the vulnerability.  The report indicates that both buffer overflow and format string vulnerabilities may be present in the product.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the Oracle server.  Because the server typically runs with system privileges, a remote user could obtain system level privileges on the server.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: IBM DB2 Database Software for Windows Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in IBM's DB2 for Windows.  The denial of service vulnerability allows remote users to crash some DB2 application processes.
It is reported that IBM DB2 for Windows runs two services that are subject to denial of service attacks: db2ccs.exe (port 6790) and db2jds.exe (port 6789). 

A remote user can cause these services to crash by initiating a telnet session on the service's port number, sending one byte, and then closing the telnet session.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can cause the db2ccs.exe and db2jds.exe services to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The vendor is reportedly preparing a fix for release this month.

Title: (CIAC Issues Advisory L-108) Re: Oracle Database's Net8 (SQL*Net) Listener Process Allows Remote Users to Deny Service to Other Users
Version(s): Various versions depending on which vulnerability 1) Oracle 7.3 and 8i on Unix; 2) Oracle 8.0 and later on all platforms; 3) Oracle8i on Sun Solaris; 4) all versions
Description:
Internet Security Systems has reported that there are several vulnerabilities with the Oracle database's listener process that allow remote users to prevent other users from accessing the database.
ISS has reportedly identified four vulnerabilities in the the Oracle listener service.

1) The first vulnerability can be triggered by a large Offset_to_data value.  When a remote user connects to an Oracle database, a connection is first made to the
listener process. This initial packet contains various command data, as well as a header field that indicates the offset to the Oracle command data. If the remote user sets the offset to a arbitrarily large value (that ISS does not specify), the listener will crash.

2) The second vulnerability is due to an incorrect requester_version value.  In the initial connection packet, a header field indicates the version of the client drivers and the offset to the Oracle command data.  If the driver version specified does not match to the appropriate offset to the command data, the listener will crash.

3) The third vulnerability is due to an overly small Maximum Transport Data Size.  In the initial connection packet, a header field is supplied by the remote user to indicate the maximum transport data size of the client s network. If this value is is set to 0, the listener will crash.

4) The fourth vulnerability is due to a fragmentation processing error.  If the first packet of a fragmented command is sent repeatedly and if the remainder of the command is not sent, the listener will hang waiting for the reassembly of the command.
Impact': These vulnerabilities allow a remote user to prevent other users from accessing the database.
Solution:
Oracle has reportedly fixed the first offset-to-data vulnerability in Oracle9i and is backporting the fix to supported Oracle 8i Releases 8.1.7 and 8.1.6 on all Unix platforms.

Oracle has reportedly fixed the second vulnerability (incorrect requester version) in Oracle9i and is backporting the fix to supported Oracle 8i Releases 8.1.7
and 8.1.6 and Oracle8 Release 8.0.6 on all platforms. 

Oracle has reportedly fixed the third vulnerability (small Max Transport Data Size) in Oracle9i and is backporting the fix to supported Oracle 8i Releases 8.1.7 and 8.1.6 on all platforms. 

Oracle has reportedly fixed the 4th vulnerability (fragmentation error) in Oracle9i and is backporting the fix to supported Oracle8i Releases 8.1.7 and 8.1.6, and supported Oracle8 Release 8.0.6 on all platforms.
Underlying OS Comments: Various platforms are vulnerable depending on which vulnerability (see Versions)

Title: Oracle 8i Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code and May Remote Users Give Full Control of the Operating System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): Oracle 8i Standard and Enterprise Editions Version 8.1.5, 8.1.6, 8.1.7 and previous versions
Description:
Network Associates COVERT Labs reported a vulnerability in the Oracle 8i database's Transparent Network Substrate (TNS) Listener that allows a remote user to execute arbitrary code on the database server.  On some platforms, this could yield full control of the operating system.
Remote client connection requests to an Oracle service are arbitrated by the TNS Listener.  A particular protocol (Net8) is implemented by the TNS Listener.

The vulnerability can reportedly be triggered with a one-packet Net8 protocol command where the remote user sends send a Type-1 (NSPTCN) packet containing the proper Net8 headers and a malformed command string with embedded arbitrary shell code.  This vulnerability can reportedly be triggered without authentication by  using unauthenticated commands such as "STATUS".

The command string includes several arguments such as "SERVICE", "VERSION", "USER" and "ARGUMENTS".  COVERT Labs reports that any of these arguments can be filled with a large amount of data to trigger the overflow (an extended argument of several thousand bytes will reportedly induce a stack overflow).
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the server.  This code may be executed with "Local System" privileges on Windows NT/2000 (giving full control of the operating system) and with "oracle" user privileges under Unix/Linux.
Solution: The vendor has reportedly released a patch (reference bug number 1489683) that is available at: http://metalink.oracle.com

Title: Oracle Database Allows Remote Users to Deny Access to the Database and Crash the Operating System
Version(s): all versions of Oracle on Windows NT
Description:
Internet Security Systems warned of a denial of service vulnerability in Oracle for Windows NT that could allow a remote user to deny access to all other users and cause the operating system to crash.
For Oracle on Windows NT, ISS reports that the Oracle listener process redirects connection requests to a new port and the Oracle Database server creates a new thread for this port.  If a connection to the new port is not made, the thread and consumed memory is reportedly lost until the Oracle Database server is restarted. As a result, a remote user can repeatedly request to be redirected but not actually connect to the assigned redirected port, causing all memory to be consumed.  The operating system will reportedly crash when an administrator subsequently attempts to log into the console.
Impact': A remote user can cause the Windows NT system running Oracle to consume 100% of available memory, crashing the operating system.  A full reboot is reportedly required to return to normal operation.
Solution: No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.  ISS describes a workaround that uses Oracle Net8's  valid node checking  feature that may reduce the risk of exposure to this vulnerability (see the Source Message for details).

Title: (CIAC Issues Bulletin L-095) Re: Microsoft SQL Server May Let Remote Authenticated Users Take Full Control of the Database Server and the Underlying Operating System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): Microsoft SQL Server 7.0, Microsoft SQL Server 2000 Gold
Description:
Microsoft has reported a vulnerability in SQL Server that may allow an authenticated remote user to obtain elevated privileges and take full control of the database server and the underlying operating system.
It is reported that when a connection to a SQL Server is terminated, the connection remains cached for a short period of time (for performance reasons).  There is apparently a SQL query method that contains a vulnerability that allows one user's query to re-use a previously terminated connection belonging to the system administrator account that still resides in the cache.

This vulnerability could allow a remote user to execute the query using the  administrator's security context, giving the remote user the ability to take any action on the database.  By running extended stored procedures, the remote user could execute arbitrary code on the server and obtain administrator-level privileges on the server (operating system).

The vulnerability reportedly can only be triggered if configured to use Mixed
Mode, which the vendor strongly recommends against, and if the user is authenticated.
Impact': A remote authenticated user could gain system administrator privileges on both the database server and the underlying server (operating system).
Solution: The vendor has released a patch.  See the Vendor URL for patch information.

Title: MDBMS Gives Remote Users Root Level Access By Executing Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the MDBMS SQL database server that allows remote users to execute arbitrary code on the server and gain root-level access to the server.
It is reported that there is a vulnerability in the processing of the \s console command.  When a user passes large buffers to the server in the form of multiple lines, the lines are appended to the end of each other.  A subsequent call to the \s command reportedly will trigger the vulnerability.

There is also reported to be a buffer overflow in the "create database" system that could be triggered by names longer than 128 bytes [Editor's note: maybe this is characters?].

An exploit transcript and an exploit script are provided in the Source Message.  The exploit script is MIME encoded.
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the server to obtain root-level access to the server's operating system.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix (v1.0).  See the Vendor URL for download instructions.

Title: Microsoft SQL Server May Let Remote Authenticated Users Take Full Control of the Database Server and the Underlying Operating System
